## Thumbprint Cookies

The filling I'm going to try this year is an amazing strawberry-lavender preserve I found near my parents' house. But you can use whatever you're craving.

2 cups sifted flour 1/2 tsp salt 1 cup butter (no substitutes!) 1/2 cup superfine sugar 2 tsp vanilla extract (or 11/2 tsp vanilla extract

and 1/2 tsp almond extract-so good) Your preferred jam or other filling 1/2 cup sifted confectioners' sugar ool

n with

1. Sift together flour and salt; set aside. Cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy; add extract(s). Slowly mix in flour, 1/2 cup at a time, until just blended. Chill dough for 1 to 2 hours.

2. Preheat oven to 325°F. Meanwhile, quickly shape dough into 1-inch balls, and space them 2 inches apart on ungreased baking sheets. Make a deep thumbprint in the center of each; fill with preferred jam or

chocolate. 3. Bake for 15 minutes, or until cookies are the color of pale sand. Transfer to wire cooling racks. 4. When cooled, dust with confectioners' sugar. Pack in tins for gifts or serve to holiday guests.

Makes 48 cookies. Per cookie: 90 calories, 4g fat, 10mg cholesterol, 55mg sodium, 12g carbs, 1g protein.

**Q** JEANINE SHERRY, M.S., ANALYSIS/CONSULTING BY

name: Healthy Brownies
transcript:
## **HEALTHY MAKEON** Brownies

The rich texture and chocolatey goodness of these bake sale favorites speak of decadence. but compare each square's 95 calories, three grams of fat, and zero cholesterol to a regular brownie's doubly high calories, nearly quadrupled fat, and 60 milligrams of cholesterol. and you'll feel virtuous (and satisfied). Our cheats? Swapping nonfat cocoa for chocolate. and cholesterol-free spread for not-so-hearthealthy butter.

**Active time 15 minutes Total time 35 minutes Makes 16 brownies** 

- 1 tsp. instant coffee powder or granules 2 tsp. vanilla extract
- 1/<sub>2</sub> c. all-purpose flour
- 1/<sub>2</sub> c. unsweetened cocoa
- 1/4 tsp. baking powder
- 1/<sub>4</sub> tsp. salt
- 1 c. sugar
- V<sub>4</sub> c. trans-fat free vegetable oil spread (60% to 70% oil)
- 3 lg. egg whites

1. Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease 8" by 8" metal baking pan. In cup, dissolve coffee in vanilla extract. 2. On waxed paper, combine flour, cocoa, baking powder, and salt.

3. In medium bowl, whisk sugar, vegetable oil spread, egg whites, and coffee mixture until well mixed; then blend in flour mixture. Spread in prepared pan. 4. Bake 22 to 24 minutes or until toothpick inserted in brownies 2 inches from edge comes out almost clean. Cool in pan on wire rack, about 2 hours. 5. When cool, cut brownies into 4 strips, then cut each strip crosswise into 4 squares. If brownies are difficult to cut, dip knife in hot water; wipe dry, and

Dry at 135°F until pliable, about 12 to 14 hours. Cut mango leather into 6-inch circles. Place parchment paper or plastic wrap between circles. Pack into a plastic storage container or vacuum package. Label and date. beef jerky Jerky is raw meat or fish which is salted or marinated and dried. Although most any type of lean meat (beef, lamb, pork or game) or fish may be used, beef jerky is the easiest to make with the most reliable results. Choose any lean cut of beef. Flank, round or sirloin tip are excellent choices. Rump, if it is lean, is also a good choice. Use only a commercial or homemade electric food dehydrator. Do not attempt to dry meat in the sun due to risk of spoilage and contamination. Freeze meat slightly to aid in slicing. Cut beef in strips, 1/2-inch thick, across the grain for a tender, slightly brittle finished product. Cut with the grain for a chewy end product. The meat must be "cured"; that is, treated in such a way to prevent spoilage. Dry cures are salt and seasonings rubbed on the meat surface. Brine cures are marinades or liquid seasoning mixtures in which the meat is soaked for a period of time. Vacuum packaging sliced meat and marinade will reduce the length of time it takes for the marinade to penetrate the meat. Not only is this method quicker, but it allows the narinade to penetrate deeper, locking in the great taste. Dry meat in an electric dehydrator at 145°F. If fat droplets appear having the drying process, blot meat with a paper towel. To test a slice of near, allow to cool. It should bend but not break. Jerky must be brought to an internal temperature of 160°F just prior as deging as immediately after drying. Two methods are recommended: sear mane errige in merinade before drying by boiling 5 minutes. Or, heat ketspitcated meat arrips to an over at 77% for 10 minutes after the drying ### Soy Jerky Yield: about 12 ounces of jerky sauce - 3 pounds lean beef - (flank, round or sirloin tip) - 3/4 cup soy sauce - 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce 1/4 cup brown sugar - 1 teaspoon onion powder - 1 clove garlic, crushed - 1/2 teaspoon cracked pepper **URNUMERIA** 1/4 teaspoon liquid smoke (optional) Cut beef into strips 1/2-inch thick. Combine marinade ingredients in a large, glass baking dish. Add strips of beef, cover and refrigerate overnight. Drain beef slices. Dry in an electric dehydrator at 145°F until pliable. Package in home canning jars, plastic storage container or vacuum package. Label and date. rubs Dry rubs are used for the intense complement of flavors they impart, and the crusty coating they wrap around a wide variety of meat, poultry, seafood and game. Rubs made fresh surpass the spice blends or seasoning packets available in stores. They are easy to make even if you do not grow all the ingredients in your back yard. However, you can take full advantage of fresh herbs and other edibles you do grow. When purchasing ingredients to fill-in where you do not have your own supply, select whole spices and herbs, grinding them as needed. Preparing dry rubs takes no more than a few minutes. Ingredients can be crushed with a mortar and pestle, ground in a hand-held grinder or pulsed in a food processor. Be careful when using a food processor that the mixture does not break down too fat, causing natural oils to release. If this happens the rub will need to be used quickly because the oils will turn rancid.

2 cups milk 4 egg yolks 3/4 cup sugar 1/3 cup flour Pinch of salt 1 tablespoon butter or margarine 1 tablespoon vanilla or

## Coconut Cheese Pie

- **A PRE**

- 3 tbsp. lemon juice

Spread butter evenly over bottom and sides of 9-inch pie pan. Press 11/3 cups of the coconut into butter, forming a shell. Place 1 cup of the coconut, the eggs, sugar, cheese and lemon juice in blender or food processor. Blend until smooth, about 11/2 minutes. Pour into coconut shell. Sprinkle remaining coconut in a ring around top and in center. Bake at 325° for 30 minutes: If coconut on top browns quickly, cover with a circle of aluminum foil.) Serve warm or cool; refrigerate any leftover pie.

## Chocolate Pecan Pie

- 1 pkg. (4 oz.) Baker's® German's® sweet chocolate
- 3 tbsp. butter or margarine
- V<sub>3</sub> cup sugar
- cup light corn syrup
- 3 eggs, slightly beaten
- tsp. vanilla
- cup coarsely chopped pecans
- unbaked 9-inch pie shell Coffee Topping (optional)

Melt chocolate and butter in small saucepan over very low heat, stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Bring sugar and corn syrup to boil in separate saucepan over high heat, stirring until sugar is dissolved. Reduce heat and boil gently 2 minutes, stirring occasionally. Remove from heat and stir in chocolate mixture. Pour slowly over eggs, stirring constantly. Stir in vanilla and nuts. Pour into pie shell. Bake at 375° for 45 to 50 minutes, or until filling is completely puffed across top. Cool. Garnish with Coffee lopping.

Coffee Topping: Dissolve 1 teaspoon Maxwell House" or Nuture" instant coffee in 1 teaspoon water. Fold into 1 cup thawed Cook Whip<sup>®</sup> whipped topping or sweetened whipped cream.

name: Lemony Chicken & Snow Peas
transcript:
## Lemony Chicken & Snow Peas (on the cover)

Springy green veggies make this quick, nutritious dish a seasonal superstar. (Salt, pepper and oil not included in five-ingredient count).

- 11/2 lbs boneless chicken breasts, sliced into strips
  - $\frac{1}{2}$  tsp salt
  - 1/4 tsp pepper
  - 2 Tbsp olive oil
- 12 oz trimmed snow peas OR chopped asparagus
  - (or a combination)
- 2 cups sliced mushrooms
- 3 lemons, cut into wedges, seeds removed
- 1/2 cup chicken broth

1. Season chicken with salt and pepper. In a large nonstick skillet, heat 1 Tbsp oil over medium. Cook chicken 3 to 4 minutes per side, until cooked through and slightly browned. Remove from skillet.

2. Heat remaining tablespoon of oil in skillet over medium-high. Add snow peas and mushrooms and cook briefly, about 3 minutes, stirring often until vegetables are fork-tender.

3. Return chicken to the skillet. Squeeze half the lemon wedges over chicken and vegetables. Add broth and cook until warmed through. Serve with remaining lemon wedges. Serves 4

name: Finger Foods Guide
transcript:
Appetizers whet the appetite and hint at the meal to follow. A good beginning to the meal, there should not be too many nor too much. A few appetizers are more appealing than an overwhelming wariety. If foods are to be eaten, serve with beverages for more enjoyment. Includes hors d'oeurves, beverages, or savory food served before a meal.

Appetizers to be eaten as finger foods should be bite-size. If other than fresh vegetables, they should be eaten from a wooden or plastic pick.

Choose complementary flavors for the rest of the meal to keep appetizers tantalizing. Use texture contrasts, color contrasts and a variety of shapes.

To prevent a last-minute rush, prepare some or all before the event.

## **Finger Foods**

name: Walnut Candy Recipe
transcript:
## **WALNUT CANDY**

Crunchy and sweet confection. Makes about 64 candies.

 $\frac{3}{4}$  cup honey 3/4 cup sugar 4 cups (1 pound) walnuts, coarsely chopped

1. Combine honey and sugar in a mediumsize saucepan. Bring to boiling; cook over medium heat until mixture reaches 245° on a candy thermometer, or a small amount dropped into cold water forms a soft ball.

2. Add walnuts; cook 3 minutes longer, stirring constantly. Pour into lightly oiled 8-inch square pan. Spread to even layer. Cool on wire rack 10 minutes; lightly mark the top with a sharp knife into about 1-inch squares. Let cool thoroughly; cut through completely.

To assemble each tamale, starting about 1 inch from the narrow edge of the husk, spread about 2 tablespoons of dough into a rectangle 3 inches wide and 4 inches long so one of the long sides of the tamale dough is at the long edge of the wrapper. Spoon I heaping tablespoon meat filling down center. Place 2 olive halves in the center. Fold the long edge of wrapper over the filling so it overlaps dough slightly. Fold the narrow end of husk over filling, then continue rolling. If desired, tie strips of cornhusk or a 100-percent-cotton kitchen string around center of tamale. 7. To prepare steamer, place a cone-shape piece of aluminum foil, point side up, in the center of steamer basket. Stand tamales upright around cone; place basket in steamer or large Dutch oven. (Don't pack tamales too tightly, but fill the space.) Place about 1 1/2 inches of water in the bottom of steamer. Bring to boiling. Cover steamer. Reduce heat to medium-low. Steam for 45 to 60 minutes. Tamales are done when dough easily pulls away from cornhusks and is spongy and well-cooked throughout. Makes 36 tamales. MAKE-AHEAD TIP: You can wrap tamales in foil and refrigerate up to 2 days before serving, or freeze them up to 3 months. To reheat refrigerated tamales, steam them still wrapped in the husks, for 8 to 10 minutes or until heated through. To reheat frozen tamales, take them directly from the freezer, wrapped in foil (do not pack tightly), and heat them in a 350°F oven for 11/4 to 11/2 hours. \*TEST KITCHEN TIP: For a milder tamale, use 4 dried ancho and 2 dried New Mexico peppers. name: Fish Tacos Recipe
transcript:
## Fish Tacos

## **SERVES 4**

## **INCREDIENTS**

- 2 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil
- 1 tbsp lime juice
- 2 tsp ground cumin
- 2 tsp paprika
- I tsp ground coriander
- 1/2 tsp ground red pepper
- 1/2 tsp garlic powder
- V<sub>a</sub> tsp salt
- V<sub>4</sub> tsp ground black pepper
- 1 Ib white fish (cod, snapper or tilapia)
- 8 six-inch soft taco tortillas
- avocado, sliced, optional **Garnishes: freshly** squeezed lime juice, lime crema, shredded cheese and diced onion, optional

## **INSTRUCTIONS**

O Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil. O In a small bowl, mix the olive oil, lime juice, cumin, paprika, coriander, red pepper, garlic powder, salt and pepper until combined. Dip the fish into the bowl and turn it until evenly coated with the marinade. Place the fish on the prepared baking sheet and let it marinate in the refrigerator for 15 minutes. 8 Bake 9 to 10 minutes,

until the fish is flaky when tested with a fork. Transfer the fish to a plate and break into smaller pieces using a fork.

**O** Heat the soft tortillas

according to package directions. Divide the fish evenly on the tortillas. Top each taco

with sliced avocado, if using. If desired, top with fresh lime juice, lime crema, shredded cheese and diced onion.

TWO POPULAR old-fashioned cakes, the Scripture Cake and the Tomato Soup Cake, are enjoying a nostalgic revival. Both are moist and fruit-filled, keep very well and are rich enough not to need a frosting.

Bible, the Scripture Cake may originally have been created to encourage people to read their Bibles more. We give both the ingredient and a biblical reference so you can look up the passage. The Tomato Soup Cake was originally made with canned tomatoes, and was revived in the '20's when canned condensed soups became popular. It's delicious, and your family will never guess its unusual ingredient!

## **Swedish Meatballs**

- V<sub>4</sub> cup finely chopped onion V<sub>4</sub> cup fine, dry bread crumbs 1/3 cup water  $1/3$  cup cream 3/4 pound ground beef, fairly lean 1/4 pound ground pork  $\frac{1}{2}$  - 1 tsp. salt  $\frac{1}{4}$  tsp. pepper

## dash of cloves and allspice

Put liquid in a blender. Add onion and run till onion is chopped finely. Add bread crumbs and seasoning. Mix with beef and pork in a bowl. Make sure all is well blended. Roll the meatballs and put them on a cookie sheet or roasting

## pan.

Heat oven to 425 - 450 degrees. Put in the pan of meatballs and bake them until they are brown. (Sometimes I turn them halfway into the cooking or shake the pan so they turn). Later you can use the drippings in the pan for gravy or use the packaged gravy from Ikea. I put the meatballs in a pot and heat them up in the gravy when I am ready to serve or freeze them in the gravy.

name: Salad Recipes
transcript:
Personally. I hate to make salads. Whenever people ask what they can bring to dinner, I blurt out "salad" without a moment's hesitation. Maybe that's because I'm not so good at making them. My friend Sandi, on the other hand, makes a faller salad. Here are her rules:

- 1. Use a good homemade salad dressing (see recipes).
- 2. Dress the salad in moderation-don't drown the greens.
- 3. Use greens that actually have some. flavor-arugula, spring mix, frisée, spinach, radicchio, máche, watercress and endive.
- 4. Consider contrasts in your saladsweet dried cranberries or raisins with sharp feta cheese, rich walnuts with bright crisp radishes or carrots.
- 5. Actually toss the salad. This way all the ingredients get coated with the dressing. (There's a reason it's called a "tossed" salad.) -Jill Melton

## **Homemade Ranch** Dressing

Because it's a best-selling salad dressing and is served with everything from chicken wings to pizza, we felt we owed it to readers to print a recipe for homemade ranch dressing (and because homemade is so much better than the bottled version). It's ridiculously easy to make. You'll never go back to the bottle.

name: Carrot Cake Recipe
transcript:
## **What's Cooking?**

Carrots are not always used in soups or salads or even eaten by rabbits, but can be an ingredient in a dessert!

## Carrot Cake

Submitted by Maggie Posada, Purchasing Intermediate Clerk

- 2 Cups of flour
- 11/2 Tsp soda
- Tsp salt
- Eggs
- Medium can of pineapple (crushed)
- 1½ Cups of chopped nuts
- 2 Tsp baking powder
- 2 Tsp cinnamon
- 2 Cups of sugar
- 11/4 Cups of wesson oil
- 2 Cups grated carrots

Sift all the dry ingredients:

Mix oil, sugar, and eggs. Beat well after each ingredient. Now add carrots, pineapple and nuts. Mix entire mixture well. Bake 3500 for about 40 minutes or until well done. Makes three layers.

## **Cake Frosting**

- 1/3 Box powdered sugar
- 1 Cube of margarine
- 8 oz package of philadelphia cream cheese
- 1 Tsp of vanilla

Mix these ingredients well. Spread on cake when it is thouroughly cooled.

transcript: HAM AND LIMA BAKE: Cover 1 pound dried limas with 6 cups water and bring to boil. Boil 2 minutes. Cover, let stand 1 hour, then cook until tender. Drain; reserve 1/2 cup liquid. name: Pot Roast Recipes
transcript:
# **Look Ahead for Lively Leftovers**

Cooking up a little extra on weekends can be the key to made-in-minutes meals during the rest of the week.

LEFTOVERS can make a quick and easy meal during the middle of the week-without looking or tasting the same the second (or even third) time around!

Each issue, we will feature hearty weekend-meal menus that include "planned" leftovers-along with speedy weekday recipes to use them up.

This time, you can start by treating your family to Favorite Pot Roast or Turkey Breast with Gravy (see the recipes on these pages).

Later, you can surprise them with a whole different meal or two using the leftovers (also included here).

## **FAVORITE POT ROAST**

simmer 45 minutes longer or until meat and vegetables are tender. Remove the roast and vegetables to a serving platter, keep warm. Discard bay leaf. Skim fat from pan juices; add water to maasure 2 cups. Mix flour and remaining water until smooth, stir into juices. Cook and stir until thickened and bubbly; cook and stir 1 minute longer. Stir in browning sauce if desired. Season with salt and pepper. Slice roast, serve with vegetables and gravy. Yield: 8 servings.

#### **BEEF PASTIES**

We had lots of leftovers when we sampled Leona's pot roast in our test kitchen, so our staff came up with this recipe for fast-to-fix pasties. Just tuck the cooked roast beef, carrots, potatoes and onion into pie pastry-your family will be amazed at the tender and flaky results!

Moisten edges with water; fold dough over filling and press the edges with a fork to seal. Place on an ungreased baking sheet. Repeat with remaining pastry and filling. Cut slits in top of each; brush with cream. Bake at 450° for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown. Yield: 4 servings. \*Editor's Note: If using purchased pre-rolled pastry, cut each circle in half. transcript:
## **ALMOND BRITTLE**

One of the easiest candias to make, and one that deserves its popularity.

Makes about % pound.

1 cup sugar

cup light corn syrup

cup water

teaspoon salt

tablespoon butter or margarine

cup whole unblanched

almonds (or peanuts)

1 teaspoon baking soda

1. Combine sugar, corn syrup, water, salt and butter in a large saucepan. Cook, stirring constantly, until sugar dissolves. Cover pan for 1 minute to allow the steam to wash down the sugar crystals that cling to side of pan, or wipe down the crystals with a damp cloth. 2. Uncover pan; insert candy thermometer. Cook without stirring until candy thermometer reaches 270° (soft crack stage, where syrup, when dropped into very cold water, separates into hard but not brittle threads). **3.** Remove from heat; stir in almonds; return to heat. Continue cooking until candy thermometer reaches 300° (hard crack stage, where syrup, when dropped into very cold water, separates into threads that are hard and brittle). 4. name: Sourdough Cornmeal Bread
transcript:
## **Sourdough Cornmeal Bread**

Soften 1 package yeast in 2 C warm water.

Add and mix well: 3/4 C starter  $1/4$  C oil 1/4 light molasses 2 t salt 2 C yellow commeal 6 C regular flour to make a stiff dough

Turn dough onto a board coated with about 1/4 C flour and with well-floured hands, knead until dough is smooth, about 5 minutes. Add more flour if needed to prevent dough from sticking.

Place dough in a greased bowl, turn over to grease top, cover, and let rise in a warm place until double in bulk about 1 1/2 hours.

Punch down dough and divide in half. Knead each gently on a lightly floured board until it has a smooth surface. Shape each into a round, lift and smooth top by pulling down gently and pinching a seam underneath.

Place loaves as shaped on lightly greased baking sheets; cover lightly with clear plastic film and let rise in warm place till double about 1<sup>1/2</sup> hours.

Bake 375 about 30 to 35 minutes until rich golden brown. Cool

on racks.

SURE-JELL For Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Premium Fruit Pectin to 1-1/2 cups water in small saucepan. stirring constantly. Bring to boil on medium heat; boil 2 min., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. 3 Trial Batch: Measure 1 cup unset jam or jelly into small bowl. Add 2 Tbsp. sugar; stir 3 min. or until completely dissolved. Add 1 Tbsp. of the pectin mixture; stir an additional 3 min. Immediately pour into one of the prepared containers. Cover and let stand up to 24 hours before checking to see if set. Meanwhile, store remaining pectin mixture in refrigerator. 4 Remainder of Batch: If Trial Batch sets satisfactorily, prepare remaining jam or jelly, remaking no more than 8 cups of jam or jelly at one time and using same directions as for Trial Batch with the above-listed measures of sugar and pectin mixture for each 1 cup of jam or jelly. Pour into prepared containers. Discard any leftover pectin mixture. ## What to Do if Your Cooked Jam or Jelly Doesn't Set 1 Prepare Jars as directed in Cooked Jam directions on other side. 2 Prepare Pectin Mixture: Slowly stir contents of 1 pkg. SURE-JELL For Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Premium Fruit Pectin into 1-1/2 cups cold water in small saucepan. Bring to boil on medium heat; boil 2 min., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. 3 Trial Batch: Measure 1 cup unset jam or jelly, 2 Tbsp. sugar and 1 Tbsp. Pectin Mixture (from step 2) into small saucepan. Bring mixture to full rolling boil (a boil that doesn't stop bubbling when stirred) on high heat, stirring constantly. Boil 30 sec., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam. Pour jam or jelly into prepared jar; cover. Let stand 24 hours before checking set. Refrigerate remaining pectin mixture. 4 Remainder of Batch: Do not remake more than 8 cups of jam or jelly at one time. If Trial Batch sets follow the recipe above, using listed measures of sugar and Pectin Mixture for each 1 cup of jam or jelly. Measure jam or jelly into stockpot. Bring to full rolling boil; boil 30 sec., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam with metal spoon. Ladle jam or jelly into prepared jars. Follow boiling water bath method to process jars. Discard any leftover pectin mixture. ## **ALTITUDE CHART** At altitudes above 1,000 feet, increase processing time 8,001-10,000 6,001-8,000

## What to Drink

"There are so many bold flavors in this recipe that you need to choose a wine with good body," says Jean Luc Le Dû, restaurant Daniel's wine director. "And with all that citrus juice and zest in the chicken, it's best to pair it with something low in acidity." Le Dû recommends a white Châteauneuf-du-Pape, particularly La Bernardine 2002 from Chapoutier (\$45). "The 2002 vintage was a difficult one for red Châteauneufs," he says, "but a great one for the whites because the grapes were picked before the rain." transcript:
## Chocolate Almond Biscotti

- 2 cups (12-ounce package) NESTLE **TOLL HOUSE Semi-Sweet Chocolate** Morsels, divided
- 2 cups all purpose flour
- **K** cup NESTLÉ TOLL HOUSE Baking Cocoa
- 11% teaspoons baking powder
- X teaspoon baking soda
- X teaspoon salt
- 1/2 cup granulated sugar

- X cup packed brown sugar
- X cup (X stick) butter or margarine, softened
- X teaspoon vanilla extract
- X teaspoon almond extract
- 3 eggs
- cup slivered almonds, toasted **Chocolate Coating (optional** recipe follows)

Microwave 1 cup morsels in small, microwave-safe bowl on HIGH (100%) power 1 minute; stir. Microwave at additional 10- to 20second intervals, stirring until smooth. Cool to room temperature.

Combine flour, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda and salt in medium bowl. Beat granulated sugar, brown sugar, butter, vanilla and almond extracts in mixer bowl until crumbly. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each. Beat in melted chocolate. Gradually beat in flour mixture. Stir in almonds. Chill for 15 minutes or until firm. Shape dough with floured hands into 2 loaves (3 inches wide by 1 inch high) on 1 large or 2 small greased baking sheet(s).

Bake in preheated 325°F. oven for 40 to 50 minutes or until firm. Let stand 15 minutes. Cut into 3/4-inch-thick slices; turn slices on their sides. Bake for 10 minutes on each side or until dry. Remove to wire racks to cool completely. If desired, dip each biscotti halfway into Chocolate Coating, pushing mixture up onto cookie with a spatula; shake off excess. Place on waxed-paper-lined baking sheets. Chill for 10 minutes or until chocolate is set. Store biscotti in airtight containers in cool place or in refrigerator. Makes 2/2 dozen biscotti.

## Old-World Manicotti

Ingredients

12 large manicotti shells

4 cups shredded mozzarella cheese, divided

2 cups ricotto cheese

6 tablespoons chapped tresh basil or 2 tablespoons dried basi

1 (26-ounce) jar prepared spaghetti sauce, divided

**1/2 cup grated Parmesan or** Romano cheese

Preheat oven to 350°F. Spray  $13 \times 9$ -inch baking dish with nonstick cooking spray.

**Cook** pasta  $\angle$  according to package directions. Drain; rinse with cool water. Let pasta dry on paper towels.

For filling, in  $J$  medium bowl, stir together 3 cups mozzarella with the ricotta and fresh basil. Using a teaspoon, carefully stuff pasta shells with prepared cheese mixture.

> 10197 20125 1018 C MMI International Masters Publishers Inc. under license. Grandma's Kitchen: Treasured Family Recipes The AIR Public in USA To collect more recipes, please contact Grandma's Kitchen: Treasured Family Recipes, 948 Plaza Drive, Montoursville, PA 17754 820 www.grandmaskitchenrecipes.com

## grandma's secrets

Another method Grandma used to stuff the cooked manicotti was to "pipe" the filing into the pasta. First, Grandma would put the cheese mixture in a large, heavy-duty resealable plastic food storage bag. She would sea the bag and then cut off one corner, making the cut about the same size as the manicotti opening. Then she would gently squeeze the bag to fill the pasta with the cheese mixture.

Spoon 2 cups I spaghetti sauce into prepared baking dish. Arrange stuffed pasta over sauce. Pour remaining spaghetti sauce over top of pasta. Sprinkle with remaining mozzarella.

 $\Gamma$  Bake manicotti for 15 minutes. Sprinkle with the Parmesan; bake for 10 minutes longer. Serve immediately.

Wash jars and screw bands in hot, soapy water; rinse with warm water. Pour boiling water over flat lids in saucepan off the heat. Let stand in hot water until ready to use. Drain well before filling. - 3. Prepare fruit as directed in following charts. For berries, crush 1 cup at a time, using a potato masher for best results. If using food processor, pulse to chop. DO NOT PUREE. Jam should have bits of fruit. - 4. Measure exact amount of prepared fruit (or juice for jelly) into 6- or 8-quart saucepot. Try Sure-Jell for Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Fruit Pectin for no- or low-sugar jams and jellies. - 6. Stir 1 box pectin into fruit or juice in saucepot. Add 1/2 teaspoon butter or margarine to reduce foaming, if desired. - 7. Bring mixture to full rolling boil (a boil that doesn't stop bubbling when stirred) on high heat, stirring constantly. - 8. Stir in sugar quickly. Return to full rolling boil and boil exactly 4 minutes for JAMS and 2 minutes for JELLIES, stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam with metal spoon. - 9. Ladle quickly into prepared jars, filling to within 1/8 inch of tops. Wipe jar rims and threads. Cover with two-piece lids. Screw bands tightly (see Note on reverse side)\*. Place jars on elevated rack in canner. Lower rack into canner. Water must cover jars by 1 to 2 inches; add boiling water if needed. Cover; bring water to gentle boil. Process jams 10 minutes; jelly 5 minutes. Adjust processing time according to Altitude Chart (on reverse side). Remove jars and place upright on a towel to cool completely. After jars cool, check seals by pressing middle of lid with finger. (If lid springs back, lid is not sealed and refrigeration is necessary.) 10. Let stand at room temperature 24 hours (or time indicated on recipe). Store unopened jams and jellies in cool, dry, dark place up to 1 year, Refrigerate opened jams and jellies up to 3 weeks. **CONTRACTOR DE REALITA**

name: Fruit Pectin Recipe
transcript:
## **PREMIUM FRUIT PECTIN**

## before you start-

## important tips for success

Use firm ripe fruit for best flavor and set. Over-ripe fruit makes a soft set. Under-ripe fruit makes a firm set.

Buy new, flat jar lids for a good seal.

Always use clean jars. Thoroughly wash jars or containers before starting.

Use only the Sure-Jell® pectin product specified in the recipes to insure a proper set. Pectin products are not interchangeable.

Measure ingredients exactly. Spoon sugar into dry (metal or plastic) measuring cups. Scrape excess sugar from top of cup with a straight-edged knife. Use liquid (glass or plastic) measuring cups with a pour spout to measure prepared fruit. (Use amount of sugar specified in each recipe. ALTERING RECIPES or INGREDIENTS could cause a set failure.)

Some jams and jellies may take up to 2 weeks to set. See individual recipes.

To make homemade jam & jelly with less sugar, look for Sure-Jell<sup>®</sup> for Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes in the pink box.

## quick & easy freezer jam directions

(Takes about half the time of cooked method, softer set, fresh fruit taste.)

- 1. Wash and rinse plastic containers with tight fitting lids. Use 1 to 2 cup size containers.
- 2. Prepare fruit as directed in following chart. (For berries, crush 1 cup at a time, using a potato masher for best results. If using food processor, pulse to very finely chop. DO NOT PUREE. Jam should have bits of fruit.)
- 3. Measure exact amount of prepared fruit along with lemon juice (if called for in recipe) into a large bowl.
- 4. Measure exact amount of sugar into separate bowl. (REDUCING SUGAR OR USING SUGAR SUBSTITUTES WILL RESULT IN SET FAILURES.) Try Sure-Jell for Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Fruit Pectin for no- or low-sugar jams and jellies.
- 5. Gradually stir 1 box pectin into fruit. Mix thoroughly. Set aside 30 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes to dissolve pectin thoroughly.
- 6. Pour 1 cup light corn syrup into fruit mixture. Mix well. This prevents sugar crystallization during freezer storage.

name: Kentucky Pecan Pie
transcript:
## **A Favorite Dessert** For Thanksgiving

D EAR READERS: If you want to treat for Thanksgiving, this column is for you. Otherwise, skip DEAR ABBY today.

Dear Abby

Nearly 15 years ago. I was honored at a dinner party at the Phoenix Hotel in Lexington. Ky. Pecan pie was served for dessert. But what pecan pie! Never had I tasted anything so delicious. After dinner I went to the kitchen to congratulate the party chef. He was so pleased, he gave me the recipe.

vanilla and mix well. Add slightly beaten eggs. Pour into a 9 inch UNBAKED pie shell. Sprinkle pecans over all. Bake in pre-heated 350° oven for approximately 45 minutes. When cool, you may top with whipped cream or ice cream ... but nothing tops this!

Abigail Van Euren

Please let me know how your cheese-

I tried it at home. Mine was every bit as good as his. And it was so easy to make that I wrote and asked permission to share the recipe with my readers. He cooperated, and I published it.

Notes came by the thousands saying, "That was the best pecan pie my family has ever tasted." So here is the recipe:

## **KENTUCKY PECAN PIE**

1 cup white corn syrup 1 cup dark brown sugar  $\frac{1}{3}$  teaspoon salt  $\frac{1}{2}$  cup melted butter (or margarine) 1 teaspon vanilla 3 whole eggs (slightly beaten) 1 heaping cup shelled whole pecans Combine syrup, sugar, salt, butter,

cake ano/or pecal pie turned out.

## \* \* \*

A ND DONT forget to have one of the  $\perp$  children say the blessing. (Or say it yourself.) Here is mine:

"Oh, heavenly Father, we thank Thee for food and remember the hungry. We thank Thee for health, and remember the sick. We thank Thee for friends, and remember the friendless. We thank thee for freedom, and remember the enslaved. May these remembrances stir us to service-that Thy gifts to us may be used for others. Amen."

Have a wonderful Thanksgiving, and may God bless you and yours.

LOVE. ABBY

For Abby's booklet, "How to Have a Lovely Wedding," send \$1 to Abigail Van Buren, 132 Lasky drive, Beverly Hills, **Calif. 90212.**

name: Spicy Pork Tamales
transcript:
## Spicy Shredded Pork Tamales

~1/2 lb. pork cubes trimmed of fat (trimmed weight), about 3 1/2 cups. ~1 packet taco seasoningmix ~1 (10 oz.) can enchilada sauce ~1 (4oz) can diced green chiles ~1 medium onion, peeled and chopped. ~3 cups mesa flour ~1/3 cup shortening ~2 1/2 cups chicken broth ~1 1/2 tsp, each salt and baking powder ~ dried corn husks, soaked in hot water overnight Salsa, sour cream and quacamole.

In a medium saucepan combine pork with taco seasoning mix, enchilada sauce, chiles and onion. Cover and simmer for 11/2 hours. Remove cover and cook over medium high heat for about 20 minutes or until most of the liquid has been absorbed. Let it cool slighlty and shred, using two forks. Meanwhile, to prepare tamale dough, place masa flour and shortening in a large bowl; cut in shortening. Using a mixer, beat in broth until mixture is about the constistency of thick cake batter. (Add a little more broth if mixture is too thick.) Using the largest of the cornhusks, spread about 1/4 cup of the masa dough in a square in the center of the husk. Place a few tablespoons of the shredded pork filling in the center of the masa. Roll up the cornhusks so that the masa meets to enclose filling. Tear 1/4-inch strips from extra cornhusks and tie each end of the tamale tightly. Repeat with remaining masa and filling. Place a rack or steamer basket in a very large stockpot (or use 2 pots). Stand tamales up in the pot, being careful not to overcrowd. (Place additional cornhusks between tamales to get them to stand up.) Place water in the pot until it is just below tamales. Cover and steam for about 1 hour or until masa dough is firm. Serve with salsa, sour cream and guacamole.

Makes about 20 tamales.

transcript:
## Original Nestlé® Toll House® **Chocolate Chip Cookies**

- 2% cups all-purpose flour
  - 1 teaspoon baking soda
  - teaspoon salt
- 1 cup butter or margarine, softened
- **% cup granulated sugar**
- **% cup packed brown sugar**

- I teaspoon vanilla extract
- 2 eggs
- 2 cups (12-ounce package) NESTLE **TOLL HOUSE Semi-Sweet Chocolate Morsels** 
  - cup chopped walnuts

Combine flour, baking soda and salt in small bowl. Beat butter, granulated sugar, brown sugar and vanilla in large mixer bowl until creamy. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each. Gradually beat in flour mixture. Stir in morsels and walnuts. Drop by rounded tablespoon onto ungreased baking sheets.

Bake in preheated 375°F. oven for 9 to 11 minutes or until golden brown. Let stand for 2 minutes; remove to wire racks to cool completely. Makes about 5 dozen cookies.

Slice-and-Bake Cookie Variation: Prepare dough as above. Divide in half; wrap each half in waxed paper. Chill for 1 hour or until firm. Shape each half into 15-inch log; wrap in waxed paper. Chill for 30 minutes.\* Cut into 1/2-inch-thick slices; place on ungreased baking sheets. Bake in preheated 375°F. oven for 8 to 10

minutes or until golden brown. Let stand for 2 minutes; remove to wire racks to cool completely. Makes about 5 dozen cookies.

## **Better Baking with Butter and Margarine**

For baking, the Nestlé Test Kitchen suggests using butter or regular stick margarine for best results. However, if you prefer using a lower-fat margarine, choose one with no less than 60% vegetable oil.

## \*Note: Logs may be stored in refrigerator for up to 1 week or in freezer for up to 8 weeks.

name: Centsible Foods Recipes
transcript:
# Centsible Foods—Fast and Frugal

**Counting pennies as** well as minutes? These quick dishes will please your pocketbook as well as your palate!

WHILE they may save time, storebought packaged entrees and carryout restaurant meals aren't always moneysavers. So look here each issue for "centsible" express-eating alternatives that are as economical as they are appetizing. The payoff? Prompt meals and a plumper pocketbook.

# PASTA SHELLS AND PEPPERS

"Tomatoes and green peppers spooned over the top give this easy-to-prepare macaroni and cheese fresh homemade taste," shares Sharon Ann Sluski from West Ossipee, New Hampshire. Our test kitchen figures her thrifty main dish costs just 94¢ per serving.

## 1 cup cubed day-old bread Pinch onion salt

Pour the oil into an 8-in. square baking pan; add garlic. Bake at 325° until garlic is lightly browned, about 3-4 minutes. Add bread and onion salt; stir to coat. Bake 10-12 minutes longer or until the bread is lightly browned, stirring frequently. Store in an airtight container. Yield: 6 (2-tablespoon) servings.

ketchup, salt and chili powder, mix well. Bring to a boil. Add hot dogs; return to a boil. Reduce heat, cover and simmer for 5-8 minutes or until heated through. Serve over rice. Sprinkle with bacon. Yield: 8 servings.

### **MAGIC APPLE PIE**

- 1 package (1 pound) medium shell pasta
- 4 medium green peppers, cut into 1-inch chunks
- 1 tablespoon butter or margarine
- 1 can (28 ounces) crushed tomatoes, undrained
- 1-1/2 teaspoons sugar
  - 1 teaspoon salt
  - 1/4 teaspoon pepper
  - 1 pound process American cheese, shredded

Fresh basil and/or oregano, optional

Cook pasta according to package directions. Meanwhile, in a skillet, saute peppers in butter for 2-3 minutes or until crisp-tender. Stir in tomatoes, sugar, salt and pepper; heat through. Drain pasta; stir in cheese until melted. Spoon into bowls; top with tomato mixture. Garnish with basil and/or oregano if desired. Yield: 6 servings.

transcript:
## **One Tequila, Two Recipes**

## Make this:

Margarita Chicken Prep: 10 minutes Marinate: 1 hour Cook: 10 minutes Serves: 4

Place 4 boneless, skinless chicken breasts in a resealable bag and add 3/4 cup margarita mix. 6 tbsp. fresh lime juice, 6 tbsp. Patrón Tequia. 1/4 cup orange liqueur, 1/2 tsp. salt and 1/4 tsp. peoper. Seal and refrigerate for 1 hour. Grill or cook chicken in skillet for about 5 minutes per side or until cooked through. 1 cup cooked chicken, pork, shrimp or turkey, cut into small dice V<sub>2</sub> cup finely sliced white onion, cut into 1-inch pieces  $V<sub>2</sub>$  cup fresh bean sprouts 10 fresh or frozen snow pea pods, cut on diagonal in 1/4-inch pieces

# **More cooking with Jill St. John**

**If Jill puts on a birthday party,** designed to please pint-sized palates, in the March 18-20 issue of USA WEEKEND.

**Photos by Teri Sandison** Food styling by Jean Carey/Kitchen Consultants

USA WEEKEND/FEB. 19-21, 1988

#### 20 pieces (about 5 spears) cooked asparagus, cut on diagonal into **1-inch pieces** $\frac{1}{3}$ cup sliced mushrooms V<sub>4</sub> cup frozen peas, thawed 6 large eggs Salt and pepper, to taste **Vegetable oil for frying Garnish: Freshly ground pepper**

Prepare sauce: Dissolve the cornstarch in the water and mix in the 21/2 tsps. vegetable oil. Set aside. In a small saucepan, bring the stock to a simmer and then lower heat. Stir in the soy sauce and sherry or rice wine. Stir the cornstarch mixture again and gradually add to the stock. Keep stirring until sauce has thickened and has no lumps. Cover and turn off heat.

Prepare pancakes: Combine meat and all the vegetables. Briskly beat the eggs with salt and pepper until frothy. Add to the meatvegetable mixture and combine.

Add enough vegetable oil to a large, deep skillet to stand 1/4-inch-deep. Set over medium heat, and when oil is hot, ladle in enough batter to form several fat pancakes. Brown on both sides, and drain on paper towels. (You may keep pancakes warm in a 250-degree oven while making the last batches.)

To serve, place pancakes on a heated platter and cover with the hot fu yung sauce. Sprinkle with freshly ground black pepper. desired, and serve with cooked rice. Total cooking time: 15-20 minutes. Serves 4.

name: Swordfish Marinade
transcript:
## TIED SWORDFISH STEAKS

/2 cup dry white wine 3 tablespoons olive oil 2 tablespoons Lea & Perrins White Wine Worcestershire Sauce 2 tablespoons lemon paice 2 tablespoons chopped Italian parsley I teaspoon finely minced garlic coarsely ground black pepper to taste 2 swordfish steaks, 6 ounces each, 11/2 inches thick

1. In a bowl large enough to hold the fish, mix all the ingredients, except the swordfish, together. Add the swordfish steaks, and turn them in the marinade. Cover loosely and refrigerate for 30 minutes.

2. Prepare hot coals for grilling. 3. Oil the grill and cook 4 inches above hot about 3 to 4 minutes per side. The steaks shown seared on the outside and just cooked through **Serves 2** 

## **GRILLING SEAFOOD**

- When placing fish directly on a grill, be sure that the grill is well cleaned and lightly oiled.
- A hinged wire fish basket makes turning a whole fish and fillets a snap.
- While grilling, baste fish with marinades to keep them moist.
- $\Delta$  Use light oil and herb marinades for up to 30 minutes before grilling fish.

name: Dry Rub Recipes
transcript:
Dry rubs store on the shelf for 1 to 3 assurabs, depending on the blend of ingredients. Not all ingredients will age at the same rate, so the flavor of the rub may change the longer it is moved. This is one reason why it is bear to prepare small amounts and use them quickly. Rubs are sensitive to light and heat. Keep dry rubs in a home canning jar or plastic murage container and place in a cabinet to protect the rub from light and hear.

The reasoning or flavoring characteristics of a dry rub is givar. Only a small amount. I tablespoon or less, is needed to season a single fish filler, chicken breast or steak. Larger cuts of meat or whole portions of poultry and fish use about 16 cup. Depending on how the dry rub is to be used, there may be some remaining for a second use. To prevent the contamination of remaining rub during initial use, measure only the amount of rub needed for one application in a separate dish.

Rubs are often prepared using fresh ingredients. But many of the same ingredients can be used in their dry state. The time required to airdry fresh ingredients can be minimized using a dehydrator.

## Island Jerk Rub

- 6 dried habañero peppers
- 6 dried scallions
- 11/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon 1 teaspoon ground coriander
  - 1 teaspoon ground nutmeg

Recommended Use: Shrimp, chicken bease and lands lobobs. Drench most in a nerves prepared with I cablespoon between many and 2 cablespoons. water. Apply rub, using 1 rablespoon for chicken breast and 4 rable. spoons for 1 pound of shrimp or limb cubes. Let shrimp stand 2 m 4 hours; chicken and lamb cubes 4 or 6 hours in a cool place. Grill.

# vegetables

Most vegetables, from asparagus to mechini, can be dehydrated at home. Select garden fresh, top quality produce for the best results. Remember, although dried regetables retain most of their vitamin and mineral content and good flavor, the original quality cannot be improved.

All vegetables require some preparation, such as removing stems, peel. or seeds, before drying. Like fruits, uniformly cut slices or pieces result in even drying. Unlike fruits, regerables are better out slightly smaller to hasten drying time. Vegetables lose flavor and tenderness if the drying time is prolonged. Drying time varies from about 4 to 14 hours. A temperature of 125°F is recommended for most vegetables. Finished vegetables should contain about 5% moisture. When tested, vegetables should, look and feel crisp or brittle.

- 2 tablespoons whole allspice
- 1 tablespoon coarse salt
- 2 teaspoons cayenne pepper
- 1 teaspoon coarse
  - ground black pepper

Crush or grind habañero peppers, scallions and whole allspice to a coarse powder. Add remaining ingredients and grind to a uniformly coarse powder. Store in home canning jar, plastic jar or plastic storage container. Label and date.

Recommended Use: Shrimp, chicken breast, pork chops, spareribs and beef or lamb kabobs. Drench meat in a sauce prepared with 1/3 cup red wine vinegar, 2 tablespoons canola oil and 1 tablespoon soy sauce. Apply rub. Let shrimp stand 2 to 4 hours; chicken, beef and lamb cubes 4 to 6 hours; pork 3 to 4 hours and ribs overnight in a cool place. Grill.

Note: When cutting or seeding hot peppers, wear rubber gloves to prevent hands from being burned.

# Kitchen Herb Garden Rub

- 1 cup dried parsley V<sub>2</sub> cup dried oregano **We cup dried rosemary**
- 2 tablespoons dried tarragon

- I tablespoon coarse salt

- black pepper

Crush or grind herbs to a coarse powder. Stir in salt and pepper. Store in home canning jar or plastic storage container. Label and date.

Recommended Use: Chicken and fish. Coat meat lightly with olive oil. Apply rub. Let chicken and fish stand 2 to 4 hours in a cool place. Grill.

#### Lemon-Cumin Spice Rub

Vegetables can be eaten dried, but they are usually reconstituted before using. An equal volume of water and vegetables is needed. Boiling water will shorten the rehydration time.

Generally, it takes 15 minutes to 3 hours for reconstituting vegetables. depending on the texture and thickness of the vegetables.

If a vegetable is not listed in the following pages, freezing or canning may be a more suitable method of food preservation.

Pack dehydrated vegetables in home canning jars, plastic jars, plastic storage containers or vacuum package. Label and date.

#### **Asparagus**

Choose young, tender stalks. Wash; cut off tough end. Slice into 1-inch pieces. Steam blanch 3 to 4 minutes. Dry at 125°F until brittle. Rehydrate and serve in soups or with seasoned cream sauce. Water content 92%.

# Beans-Green Or Wax

Choose any variety with crisp, thick walls and small seeds. Wash: snap off ends; cut diagonally into 1-inch pieces or French cut to expose more surface area. Steam blanch 4 to 6 minutes. Freeze beans 30 minutes a tenderize; dry at 125°F until brittle. Rehydrate and use in casseroles soups and srews. Water content 90%.

## Beets

Choose any variety with deep-red color and smooth skins. Which remove all but one inch of stem and tap root. Steam about 30 minutes or until tender. Cool; peel; trim stem and tap root. Cut into he and alices or dice. Dry at 125°F until leathery. Use in soups or reconstitute a a vegetable. Water content 87%.

Cook macaroni shells as directed on package; drain and pat dry. Mix salmon, % cup of the soup, onion, 1 tablespoon wine and 1/4 teaspoon dill weed. Fill each shell with about 3 tablespoons of the salmon mixture.

Place trivet in Skillet; add 1/4 cup water. Arrange stuffed shells on trivet; cover with domed lid and place on Micro-Go-Round<sup>®</sup> in microwave oven. Microwave at High for 6 to 8 minutes, or until filling is hot. Let stand 3

## **Cinnamon French Toast**

Prepare on: All-in-One Skillet

- 2 eggs
- tablespoon milk
- teaspoon sugar
- 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- /4 teaspoon almond extract
- slices French bread, each 1-inch thick
- teaspoon butter or margarine Warm syrup or orange marmalade

Beat eggs, milk, sugar, cinnamon and almond extract with fork in large bowl. Place French bread slices in egg mixture, turning to coat. Allow to soak while preheating Skillet. Preheat Skillet at High for 5 minutes. Place butter on preheated Skillet; spread evenly across surface. Place bread slices on Skillet. Microwave at High for 1 minute; turn slices. name: Mothered Flank Steak
transcript:
## MOTHERED FLANK STEAK

4 tablespoons unsalted butter 2 medium yellow onions, peeled and sliced 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon salt freshly ground black pepper to taste 1 flank steak, about 11/4-11/2 pounds 1/2 cup beef broth 2 teaspoons Lea & Perrins Worcestershire Sauce 2 teaspoons tomato paste

1. Heat 2 tablespoons butter in a large heavy skillet. Add onion, garlic powder. salt and pepper. Cook over medium-low heat until the onions are wilted and slightly golden, about 15 minutes. Remove the onions with a slotted spoon and set aside.

2. Add remaining butter to the skillet. Increase heat to medium. Season the steak with salt and pepper and saute it until browned on the outside and pink and juicy on the inside, 3-5 minutes per

side depending on thickness. Transfer to a cutting board and keep warm.

3. Pour off the fat, and return the onions to the skillet. Stir in remaining ingredients and cook until heated through and slightly thickened about 2-3 minutes.

4. Quickly slice the steak across the grain and at an angle into thin strips. Spoon the heated sauce over the steak and serve.

**Serves 4**

## Double Chocolate Peanut Butter Thumbprint Cookies

- 11% cups all-purpose flour
  - 1/8 cup NESTLÉ TOLL HOUSE Baking Cocoa
- 11% teaspoons baking powder
  - X teaspoon salt
  - 2 cups (12-ounce package) NESTLÉ **TOLL HOUSE Semi-Sweet Chocolate**
- cup granulated sugar About 1 cup chunky or creamy peanut butter (not all-natural), divided
- 1/<sub>2</sub> cup butter or margarine, softened
- 11/2 teaspoons vanilla extract
  - 2 eggs

## Morsels, divided

Combine flour, cocoa, baking powder and salt in small bowl. Melt 1 cup morsels in small, heavy saucepan over lowest possible heat, stirring constantly until smooth.

Beat granulated sugar, 1/3 cup peanut butter, butter and vanilla in large mixer bowl until creamy. Beat in melted chocolate. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Gradually beat in flour mixture. Stir in remaining morsels. Cover; chill just until firm.

Shape dough into 11/2-inch balls. Place on ungreased baking sheets. Press 1/2-inch-deep centers with thumb. Fill each center with about /2 teaspoon peanut butter.

Bake in preheated 350°F. oven for 10 to 15 minutes or

name: Spicy Sausage Sandwiches
transcript:
## **TALIAN SAUSAGE SANDWICHES**

Spicy sausage and peppers fill a crispy

Makes 4 sandwiches.

4 Italian hard rolls 1 pound sweet or hot sausages or a combination of both 1 large onion, chopped (1 cup) 2 medium-size green peppers, halved, seeded and cut into thin strips 1 can (8 ounces) tomato sauce  $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ 

1. Cut rolls in half lengthwise; scoop out center of each bottom half to make a boat-shaped shell. Tear scooped-out bread into small pieces with your fingers, or place a little at a time into electric blender container; cover; whirl at high speed 15 seconds. Measure out 1/2 cup; reserve. (Save remainder to use as a crumb topping for a casserole.)

2. Remove sausage from casings; break into small pieces. Cook slowly in a large skillet about 15 minutes or until browned.

3. Add onions and green pepper to skillet; sauté 5 minutes or until softened. Drain off excess fat. Stir in tomato sauce. Cook over moderate heat until mixture thickens, about 10 minutes. Stir in the 1/2 cup reserved bread crumbs.

4. Place rolls on cookie sheet. Broil 5 minutes or until lightly toasted.

5. Spoon sausage mixture into rolls. Cover with tops. Secure with wooden picks; cut sandwiches in half. Serve hot with knife and fork.

name: Walnut Butter Toffee
transcript:
## **WALNUT BUTTER TOFFEE**

1 cup butter or margarine 1 cup sugar 2 tablespoons water I tablespoon light corn syrup 1 cup chopped walnuts 1/2 cup semisweet chocolate pieces

Melt butter in large heavy saucepan over low heat. Stir in sugar, water and syrup and bring to boil over medium heat, stirring constantly. Turn heat to low and simmer without stirring until candy thermometer reaches 290°. Remove from heat and stir in walnuts. Spread in greased 13x9x2inch pan. Sprinkle with chocolate pieces and let stand a few minutes until melted; spread chocolate evenly over top. Cool in pan on rack until firm and chocolate is set. Break in pieces; store airtight in single layers between sheets of waxed paper in cool dry place. Makes about 1-1/4 pounds.

name: Dinner Rolls Recipe
transcript:
## Ingredients

- 1 cup warm water (105°F to 115°F)
- 2 packages active dry yeast
- $\frac{1}{2}$  cup (1 stick) butter, melted
- 1/2 cup sugar
- 3 eggs

## **Perfectly Easy Dinner Rolls**

Stir in butter, sugar, eggs and salt. Beat in flour, 1 cup at a time, until dough is too stiff to mix (some flour may not be needed). Cover and refrigerate 2 hours or up to 4 days.

Combine the warm water and yeast in a large bowl. Let the mixture stand until yeast is foamy, about 5 minutes.

1 teaspoon salt

4-41/2 cups unbleached all-purpose flour

Additional melted butter (optional)

makes 2 dozen rolls

**Helpful Hints** 

· In this recipe, don't use quick-rising dry yeast, since it is designed to raise breads quickly.

Grease a 13- x 9-inch baking pan. Turn the chilled dough out onto a lightly floured board. Divide dough into 24 equal-size pieces. Roll each piece into a

smooth round ball; place balls in even rows in the prepared pan. Cover and let dough balls rise until doubled in volume, about 1 hour.

name: Zucchini Oven Fries
transcript:
Zucchini Oven Fries Cut 2 (12 oz) zucchini into 3-inch sticks. In a bowl mix together 1/2 cup panko bread crumbs, 1/4 cup shredded Parmesan, 1/8 tsp ground cumin, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp dried oregano, 1/4 tsp paprika and 1 tsp kosher salt. Add 2 tsp olive oil and mix with fingertips until combined. In a separate bowl beat 2 egg whites until

frothy. Toss zucchini sticks in the egg whites. Working in batches, transfer sticks to the bread crumb mixture, press crumbs onto zucchini and place on a baking sheet. Bake at 450°F until golden and just tender, about 12 min. Serve immediately. **SERVES 4 TO 6** 

Per Serving: 85 cal, 3.5g fat (1g sat), 506mg sodium, 9g carb, 4mg chol, 5g protein, 2g fiber

name: Pasta Pie & Mac Recipes
transcript:
## PASS A PIECE-A PASTA PIE

Cousin Ginny, Aunt Patsy's daughter knows "no offer!" But to her this word. "pasta," means either something afready happened, past tense, or someone better "pasta" the food real quick before Cousin David eats it all!

I onion chopped I lb ground turkey (or hamburger). 1-141/2 or stewed tomatoes, undrained 1-15 oz can tomato sauce I teaspoon thyme leaves I teaspoon basil leaves 16 teaspoon ground cumin 14 teaspoon salt dash pepper 1-11 oz can corn, drained 1-15 oz can black beans (or kidneys) 1-6 oz can small black pitted olives, drained I cup chopped green pepper 12 oz spaghetti noodles (no, Aunt Patsy doesn't have any so you'll have to use brand X!) 3 cups (12 oz) grated cheddar cheese

## **STACK A MAC**

The only thing stacked about Aunt Patsy is her macaroni? This is a "dinner version" of an ice cream sundae with toppenes.

I lb lean ground beef or turkey I cup chopped onion 1-15 or can tomato sauce L-R or can formato tauce I teaspoon dried oregano leaves I teaspoon dried basil leaves I teaspoon dried thyme leaves 14 teaspoon salt 14 teaspoon pepper 12 or Aunt Patsy's pasta, cooked, or 4 cups cooked rice 1-10 oz package frozen peas (2 cups) 8 oz cheddar cheese, grated

In a skillet, brown the meat with onion, drain off fat. Add tomato sauces, oregano, basil, thyme, salt and pepper. Simmer, stirring occasionally for 30 minutes. Meanwhile cook the pasta or rice according to instructions. Cook peas. On individual plates . . . start stacking! First mac (or rice) then the meat mixture then peas then cheese. Need a "cherry" on top? Try a chili pepper.

(Similar to Russian Stroganoff)

Cousin David used to bring home a friend called "Strop." He used to like this chicken dish so much and would help. himself to so many servings that Aunt. Patsy was always yelling ... "Stron! Fnough! Enough!"

> I small onion, chopped. 2 Ib boneless, skinless chicken breasts. cut in small cubes 2 tablespoons oil 1/3 cup butter (the real stuff!) 2/3 cup flour I teaspoon thyme dash nutmeg I cup chicken broth I cup milk 1/2 cup white wine 1/2 teaspoon salt % cup grated parmesan cheese 4 oz can mushrooms, drained, (or 1/4 lb fresh mushrooms, sliced and sauted) 8 oz sour cream (very optional - this is pretty creamy already) 12 oz of your favorite Aunt Patsy Pasta cooked according to instructions

Brown onion and turkey in large skillet. Drain any grease. Add stewed tomatoes, tomato sauce, thyme, basil, cumin, salt, and pepper. Now just let this stuff simmer for 15-20 minutes, till thicker. Dump in the drained corn, beans, olives, and green pepper. If your skillet wasn't large enough, you'll have to dump this all in a large bowl so you can mix it without decorating the counter with it! Don't squash the olives when you mix (Cousin David can't get squashed olives to stay on his fingers).

Cook the spaghetti according the directions and drain. Lightly grease two 10" pie plates and arrange the spaghetti as a crust. Cousin Ginny doesn't have 10" pie plates, so she uses 8" square pans. She says instead of pasta pies she now has a square meal!

Divide the stuff from the large bowl (unless you were one of the smart large skillet people) into the 2 "pie crusts." Sprinkle the cheese on top of both. Bake at 375° for 40 minutes. Cut and serve.

Yes, this does make alot of pie. At Aunt Patsy's house, Cousin David eats one and the whole rest of the family splits the other one. Or cut the recipe in half. Cousin Ginny freezes one for later (we think you can freeze this anyway . . .).

## APPLE MAC SALAD

Aunt Patsy would prefer a recipe for Apple Jack but we told her this was a family recipe edition.

> 2 cups cubed red apples 2 cups (dry) pasta-cooked I cup chopped celery 1/2 cup walnut pieces (or almonds) cup good quality mayonnaise 2 tablespoons lemon juice I teaspoon sugar

Mix all of the ingredients except the pasta together in a large bowl. Put the bowl in the fridge to chill. Just before serving time, cook the pasta according to directions. Rinse with cold water until cool. Drain. Add the cooked pasta to the other ingredients. Gently stir together and serve.

Quickly stir-fry the chicken and onions in a pan with the 2 tablespoons oil till the chicken is done, about 10 minutes. Remove to dish and keep warm.

Melt the 1/3 cup butter in the pan, add the flour and blend in. Dump in the thyme, salt, and dash of nutmeg. Gradually add the chicken broth, milk, and wine (sometimes we catch Aunt Patsy adding the wine to herself not the recipe!) Continue to cook and stir till the sauce boils and thickens. Now dump in the parmesan cheese and cook just a little more. Add the chicken, onions, and mushrooms and heat thoroughly. If you like the way it tastes right now, stop, you're done. But if you want it even creamier, and can handle more fat, er, richness, throw in the sour cream. Lather the sauce over a plate of noodles and serve.

The noodles and sauce concoction can also be thrown all together in a casserole dish and baked for 30 minutes, too. This was Strog's favorite version cause then he could help himself to several large spoonfuls. Strog! Enough! Enough!

name: Shrimp Cassoulet Recipe
transcript:
## A healthy winter casserole

This easy, fast recipe makes a delectable, high-protein casserole that will warm up your family and guests. Contrary to food lore, shrimp does not raise cholesterol counts.

**Hearty and Elegant Shrimp Cassoulet** 

1 Tb. olive oil 3 garlic cloves, peeled and sliced thin 1 cup chopped yellow onion 1 medium green pepper, chopped 2 19-ounce cans cannellini beans, drained and rinsed

1 14.5-ounce can tomatoes, diced

1 cup low-fat, low-sodium chicken or vegetable broth

1/2 tsp. each dried basil and thyme 1/2 cup Kalamata olives, pitted and halved % pound large shrimp (raw or cooked), shelled, develned and halved

1/2 cup dry bread crumbs V& cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese Salt and pepper, to taste

In large pan, sauté garlic, onion and green pepper in oil over medium heat till soft, about 5 minutes. Add beans, tomatoes, broth, herbs, olives, salt and pepper. Bring to simmer. Add shrimp; cook 3 minutes. Turn into large baking dish. Top with bread crumbs mixed with Parmesan. Bake in preheated 400-degree oven till bubbly, about 20 minutes. Brown top under broiler if desired. Serves 8. Per serving 2.20 caluters. 16g protein, 6 Fg fat (1.3g safe unard). 2by carbohydrates, 6 by four 580mg sadium.

name: Chicken Tortilla Soup
transcript:
## **Chicken Tortilla Soup**

## 2 Tbs. olive oil

- 2 medium-large onions, cut into medium dice
- 4 large garlic cloves, minced
- 4 tsps. chili powder
- 2 tsps. dried oregano
- 2 28-ounce cans crushed tomatoes (try fire-roasted)
- 1 quart chicken broth

- 116-ounce package frozen corn
- 24-ounce cans green chilies, chopped
- 215.5-ounce cans black beans
- 4 cups shredded, cooked chicken
- $\frac{1}{2}$  cup chopped fresh cilantro
- Tortilla chips, to serve

Heat oil in large soup kettle over medium-high heat. Add onions; sauté until tender, about 4 minutes. Add garlic cloves, chili powder and oregano; sauté 1 minute longer.

Add tomatoes, broth, corn, chilies, beans and chicken; bring to a simmer. Reduce heat and simmer. partially covered, to blend flavors, about 20 minutes. Stir in cilantro; let stand a couple of minutes. (After cooling, the soup can be refrigerated for up to 3 days. Serve warm with tortilla chips.

MAKES 4 QUARTS, SERVING 10 PER SERVING: 320 Calores 27g protein, 39g carbohydrates, 7g fat (1g saturated) 48mg cholesterol, 10g fiber, 1,188mg sodium

## **Capture hearts with** Kahlua-laced brownies

For Valentine's Day, Mother's Day or the day you can't resist a sweet treat, Kahlua Cream Praline Brownies were created to both capture and warm the hearts of brownie lovers!

They get their taste-tempting "layered look" from a rich, moist combination of praline crust, kahlua and deep chocolate brownie center, kahlua buttercream frosting and chocolate glaze topping.

Prepare Praline Crust. Melt Chocolate with shortening over very low heat. Beat eggs with sugars and vanilla until blended. Stir in cooled chocolate mixture, then Kahlua. Add flour and salt, mixing to smooth batter. Stir in pecans. Turn into prepared pan. Bake in 350 deg. F oven, about 25 minutes, until pick inserted in center comes out clean (be careful not to overbake). Cool. Spread Kahlua Butter Cream Frosting over top and place in refrigerator a half hour to set. Spread Chocolate Glaze evenly over frosting and cool until set. Cut into small squares about 11/4 inches. Makes 3 dozen.

And Kahlua Cream Praline Brownies look as good as they taste, making them a nice choice for bridal showers or buffets where special treats which do not require utensils are so convenient and welcome.

name: Egg Ideas
transcript:
Eggs are one of your best food buys. And they're so versatile and easy to prepare! For example, a dozen eggs (that's a pound and half of high-quality protein) can feed a family of 6 for less than a dollar. When eggs sell for 75¢ a dozen they're costing you only  $50<sup>4</sup>$  a pound!

**Y'S BEST FOOT** 

And with those dozen eggs you can scramble up a super supper, fry some fantastic egg sandwiches, stir up an easy but elegant quiche or turn out a hearty casserole. Here are some super-fast egg ideas to help feed your family without busting your budget.

Instant Egg Pick-Up: blend an egg, a cup of orange juice and a teaspoon of honey in a blender or shaker jar. Makes a quick and easy breakfast or a super snack. Great for kids, on-the-go moms and dads, anybody.

Egg Taco: Scramble some eggs and spoon into crisp taco shells. Drizzle on taco or hot sauce, then sprinkle with cheese, lettuce, chopped tomato, whatever. Fast to fix, fun to eat, and cheap!

name: Nut Lace Cookies
transcript:
Lasking like roughhewn jewels, Westerncours nots are framed by these grandscule curamel cookies. Thin, crisp, and shiny they make striking desserts or impressive gifts.

Fragile to bite, the cookies are much easier to make and sturdier to handle than they look. The process is simple-but it requires some careful attention.

As the caramel around the nuts bakes, it spreads into a very thin layer 5 to 6 inches in diameter. You can bake only a few cosises at a time.

while hot, the caramel is soft. As it cools, the cookies become rigid. The trick is to get them off the pan after they harden enough not to stretch and tear, but before they get so brittle they break.

Stored airtight, these cookies stay crisp. If you want to make them more than a week ahead, they should be frozen for best flavor. W you're giving them away, handcarry them-very carefully.

To create a striking visual effect and an easier-than-pie desse.t, tuck a cooky vertically into a bowl of your favorite flavor of ice cream.

## **Nut Lace Cookles**

- a cup (% lb.) butter or margarine
- a cup each light com syrup and firmly packed brown sugar
  - the allowpose four
  - cup muse whole or nati almonds, hazewatc, suchadamias, pecans, pine nuts, parachica, and walnuts, plain or swied (or eny combination of thuse nurse

and nuts. slightly. Makes 10. 118 mg sodium.

In a 1- to 2-quart pan, melt butter over low heat. Add corn syrup and brown sugar. Stir over high heat until boiling. Remove pan from heat and blend in flour

Grease and flour 12- by 15-inch or 14- by 17-inch baking sheets (they must be flat, not warped). For each cooky, place 2 tablespoons of the nut mixture about 8 inches apart on the sheet-put only 2 cookies on a pan at a time.

With your fingers, push nuts apart into a 3- to 4-inch circle or oval. Bake in a 350° oven until cookies are a rich golden brown, about 10 minutes (if you have 2 pans in the oven, alternate positions at midpoint to ensure even browning).

Remove cookies from oven and let them cool on the pan until they firm up slightly, about 2 minutes; to test, slide a spatula under a corner. If the cooky is stretchy, wait just a few seconds longer. If it is hard, slide spatula under carefully and lift onto a rack. If cookies get too hard and stick to pan, return to oven to soften

When cool, serve, or immediately package airtight in rigid container. Cookies absorb moisture and lose their crispness quickly. If you stack the cookies in the containers, separate each layer with a sheet of waxed paper to protect them from breaking and sticking together. Hold at room temperature up to I week or freeze up to I month.

Per cooky (made with 1/2 salted nuts): 178 cal.; 1.9 g protein; 16 g carbo.; 12 g fat; 12 mg chol.;

name: Sourdough Hotcakes/Waffles
transcript:
## Sourdough Hotcakes or Waffles

Recipe circa 1959 from Jan's aunt who lived in Anchorage and sent the state-side family "real" sour dough starter.

- The night before combine:
  - 1 C starter
  - 2 C lukewarm water
  - 2 C flour
  - 1 T sugar

Let stand overnight in a covered bowl in a warm place. I put it in one of the cupboards to avoid drafts.

Next morning save 1 C of above mixture and store in refrigerator in a covered jar. This is your starter.

To the remainder add the following and beat together: 2 whole eggs (for pancakes) (for waffles separate eggs and beat whites until stiff and fold in last) 1 T sugar 1 t salt 1 t soda 1/2 C undiluted canned milk Fold into the flour mixture - just enough to blend (do not

beat) then add  $1/4$  oil

Can cut down on oil for hotcakes. Can thin with additional milk. Never add extra flour after it has set over night. Makes thin, light pancakes.

In saucepan combine water, sugar, cinnamon, cloves, and lemon peel. Bring to boiling, stirring till sugar is dissolved. Reduce heat; cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Stir in lemon juice. Strain through cheesecloth. Cover tightly and refrigerate as long as 6 weeks.

To serve, pour mix into a glass or mug and add desired beverage. Use 2 tablespoons mix to  $\frac{3}{4}$  cup (6 ounces) beverage. (Serve chilled drink with ice, if desired.) Garnish with orange slices and maraschino cherries on a skewer, if desired. Makes 11/2 cups mix or enough for 12 servings.

## Low Fat Tomato Basil Soup - How to Make Low Fat, Low Calorie Tomato Basil Soup

## **Abaut.com** Low Fat Cooking

## **Tomato Basil Soup**

Be the first to write a reviews By Fiona Haynes, About.com Guide

This quick and easy, low-fat, low-calorle tomato and basil soup is a perfect soup for all seasons. All you need little bread and a green salad for a great lunch. Use vegetable broth for a vegetarian soup.

Prep Time: 10 minutes

**Cook Time: 15 minutes** 

**Total Time: 25 minutes** 

Low Fat Tomato Basil Soup Faona Haynes

- . 2 cups nonfat, low sodium chicken broth

## **Preparation:**

Gently sauté onions, celery and garlic over medium heat, until softened.

Add basil, thyme, and tomatoes, followed by chicken broth...

name: Corn Bread Recipe
transcript:
Corn Bread (Makes 12 servings) **I cup ALBERS Yellow Corn Meal** cup all-purpose flour 1/4 cup granulated sugar tablespoon baking powder I teaspoon salt 1/3 cup vegetable oil egg, lightly beaten 1 cup milk

**COMBINE** corn meal, flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in medium bowl. Combine oil, egg and milk in small bowl: mix well.

ADD milk mixture to flour mixture; stir just until blended. Pour into greased 8-inch square pan.

**BAKE** in preheated 400°F. oven for 25 minutes or until wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean. Serve warm. **NOTE:** Recipe may be doubled. Use greased  $13 \times 9$ -inch pan; bake as above. For Muffins: SPOON batter into 10 to 12 greased or paper-lined muffin cups filling 2/3 full. Bake in preheated 400°F. oven for 15 minutes. **Sweeter Corn Bread Variation: COMBINE** 1/2 cup corn meal, 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 2/3 cup granulated sugar, 1 tablespoon baking powder and 1/2 teaspoon salt in medium bowl. Combine 1/3 cup oil, 3 tablespoons melted butter or margarine, 2 eggs and 1 1/4 cups milk in small bowl. Combine as above. Pour into greased 8-inch square pan. Bake in preheated 350°F. oven for 35 minutes.

## For Muffins: SPOON batter into 18 to 20 greased or paper-lined muffin cups filling 2/3 full. Bake in preheated 350°F, oven for 18 to 20 minutes.

name: Pillsbury Bean Roll-Ups
transcript:
# leef'n bean roll-ups

# Winner in Pillsbury's 21st Bake Off

- 2 cups Pillsbury's Best All Purpose Flour\*
- 2 teaspoons baking powder
- **1/2 teaspoon salt**
- the cup butter or margarine
- % cup milk
- **K** cup molasses

### Meat Mixture

- 1 to 2 lbs. ground beef
- 2 cans (1-lb. each) pork and beans
- 2 to 4 tablespoons instant minced
- onion or 1/2 to 1 cup finely chopped onion
- the cup molasses
- W cup catsup

### **OVEN 400°**

## **6 TO 8 SERVINGS**

Prepare Meat Mixture; set aside. (No need to sift flour; measure by lightly spooning into cup and leveling off.) In large mixing bowl, combine flour with baking powder and sail. Cut in butter until crumbly. Add milk and molasses; stir just until dough clings together. On lightly floured surface, knead dough 5 to 6 times. Roll out to 12x9-inch rectangle. Spread % cup warm Meat Mixture over dough. Starting with 12-inch side, roll up; cut into twelve 1-inch slices. Pour remaining hot Meat Mixture into 12x8 or 13x9-inch (shallow 2 or 3 qt.) baking dish. Place biscuit slices on hot mixture in baking dish forming 3 rows of 4 biscuits each. (To assure doneness, place

biscuits on hot Meat Mixture.) Bake at 400° for 20 to 25 minutes until biscuits are browned and bean mixture is bubbly.

Meat Mixture: In large fry pan, brown ground beef; drain. Add beans, onion, molasses and catsup; mix well. Bring mixture to a boil; remove from heat and cover to keep warm.

\*For use with Pillsbury's Best Self-Rising Flour, omit baking powder and salt.

HIGH ALTITUDE ADJUSTMENT-5200 feet. Not necessary.

As for the bottles used to make and package these gifts, here's your chance to recycle in style. Ordinary wide-mouth glass jars (juice bottles work well) are recommended for steeping.

For the final bottling, look for unusual, attractive glassware, new or used. My own assortment is largely saved from specialty vinegars and oils, augmented by occasional thriftshop finds. Add a few spent, behind-the-bar bottles and you may never need to buy fancy new bottles, which cost about \$10 to \$15 each.

All bottles should be washed to soak off old labels and obliterate old flavors and aromas. On the day they will be filled, sterilize the bottles in boiling water for 10 minutes, drain, dry, and let cool to room temperature before adding liqueurs.

If the bottles have no caps, shop for good-quality corks or stoppers at kitchen- or wine-supply shops. The last thing you want is to have liqueur leak out of a gift bottle laid on its side.

Gift bottles, by the way, should be clearly labeled, not just with the name of the recipient and/or giver but also with the ingredients used. This applies to

Stir in lemon juice if listed in recipe. **SUPPLIES NEEDED:** Dry measuring cup, liquid measuring cup, 2 large bowls, large saucepan, ladle, jars, lids and seals. 2 Measure exact amount of sugar into large saucepan with dry measuring cup. ## **CHERRY-O CREAM CHEESE PIE**

 $(Makes 8$  servings) 1 cup Kellogg's Corp Flake Crumbs . 2 tablespoons sugar V<sub>3</sub> cup butter or margarine, melted 1 (8 oz.) package cream cheese, softened at room temperature 11/3 cups (15 oz. can) Borden Eagle Brand Sweetened Condensed Milk (only Sweetened Condensed Milk can be used) V<sub>3</sub> cup lemon juice\* (measure accurately) • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 1 (1 lb. 5 oz.) can prepared Cherry Pie Filling OR Cherry Glaze\*\* Combine Crumbs, sugar and butter or margarine; mix well.

Press evenly and firmly on bottom and sides of 9-inch pie plate. Chill. Beat cream cheese until fluffy. Gradually add Sweetened Condensed Milk; stir until well mixed. Stir in lemon juice and vanilla until well blended. Turn into prepared crust. Chill 2 to 3 hours (DO NOT FREEZE). At serving time, garnish with Cherry Pie Filling OR Cherry Glaze.

\*If frozen lemon juice concentrate is used, reconstitute according to package directions.

## **\*\*CHERRY GLAZE**

 $(Makes 1 cup)$ 

1 cup  $(1/2)$  of 1 lb. can) drained, red, tart, pitted cherries 2 tablespoons sugar • 2 teaspoons cornstarch •  $\frac{1}{2}$  cup cherry juice Drain cherries; measure juice. Combine sugar and cornstarch; stir in juice. Cook over low heat; stir constantly until thickened and clear. If desired, stir in a few drops of red food coloring. Add cherries. Cool. Spread over top of chilled cheese pie.

**VARIATION** "No Cook" Peachy Cream Cheese Pie: Add 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon to Crumb crust mixture. Reserve 2 tablespoons crumbs for top of pie. Proceed as directed above to make crust and filling. Drain well a one-pound can of sliced cling peaches. Arrange atop filling. Sprinkle with reserved crumbs. Chill.

name: Cake Recipes
transcript:
Cakes may be divided into two classes-Butter and Butterless or Sponge. A good Butter cake should be fine grained or of smooth texture. This is obtained by accurate measuring and skill in combining ingredients which require effort and time. The butter should be creamed until light colored. Fine granulated sugar should then be blended well with it. Eggs should be separated and well beaten before adding.

Dry ingredients should be sifted before and after measuring and these should be added alternately with the milk to the butter, sugar, and egg mixtures. Beaten egg whites and flavoring should be then folded into batter. Butter cakes require a moderate oven-350 to 400 degrees Fahrenheit. Sponge cakes require a slow oven-275 to 350 degrees Fahrenheit. Sponge cakes contain little liquid but great amounts of egg. Angel cake is a type of Sponge cake. Do not grease pans for sponge cakes. Frost cakes after they are cold.

Frosting should be cold when put on.

Skill is required in making good pastry. Flakiness, crispness and tenderness are characteristics of good pastry; and these are realized by the selection of good ingredients, accurate measurements and skillful mixing.

Pastry should not be made in a warm temperature.

Shortening should be worked in with a blender.

Ice water is conducive to tender pastry,

### HARWICH HERMITS

Hermits, rich with spices, plotting with fruits and nuts, originated in the seafaring town of Harwich on Cape Cod-Women made hermits for their mentols, to take on long voyages; they packed the hermits in tole canisters and theked them. away in sea chests. Grandmother went to Cape Cod in the summertime and brought this recipe home with her. It is probable that it goes back to clipper-ship days.

For filling, press desired candy piece into center of each ball and shape dough around candy so it is completely hidden. For coating, roll cookies in colored sugar crystals or decors until evenly coated or coat in powdered sugar as directed below.\* Place balls on ungreased cookie sheet before baking. Bake 14 to 17 ABOUT 4 DOZEN COOKIES \* For powdered sugar coated cookies, bake uncoated cookies as directed above. Remove to when the top minutes. Place about 3/4 cup powdered sugar in a plastic bag. Gently shake 3 to 4 cookies in process sugar until coated. Repeat with remaining cookies. Sift remaining powdered sugar over cookies.
