name: Zucchini-Mushroom Casserole
transcript:
## **B**elCrous **IMPROVISATION ZUCCHINI-MUSHROOM CASSEROLE**

## By ROLAND A. BROWNE

I am convinced that many of the really great dishes of this world have resulted from cooks' putting together the foods that just happened to be on hand. Consider beans with chill peppers; comed beef and cabbage; saverkraut with ham and sausage, cathan and hush puppies Or take Pennsylvania Dutch apple pie, containing frosh apples, black walnuts and raisins. The apples and walnuts would ripen together in the late fall, but fresh grapes would long since have gone; only dried grapes would be on hand as **TAISINS** 

Recently my wife had to take off for Washington on family concerns, leaving me to do the cooking in her absence. Like any prudent husband, I studied the contents of the refrigerator before doing any substantial food shopping. The vegetable drawer yielded the following items: 1 pound zucchini, 1/2 pound fresh mushrooms and 1/2 basket cherry tomatoes. All needed to be used promptly if they weren't to spoil. Further rummaging produced some mozzarella cheese, some Parmesan cheese and a box of bread crumbs. These seemed like promising materials for a little Italian-style cooking. They turned into one of the best casseroles I have eaten in a long time. Here's my recipe. 1 Cut 1 pound zucchini in 1/4-inch slices, spread out on paper towel, sprinkle liberally with salt and let stand about 1 hour to draw out liquid. Blot dry with another paper towel. 2 Meanwhile with damp paper towel wipe off about 1/4 pound mushrooms; slice and set aside. 3 In large skillet add just enough olive oil to coat bottom (about 2 tablespoons): heat, then quickly brown zucchini; transfer to 1-quart casserole. 4 Add more oil to skillet if necessary and sauté mushrooms and 1 tablespoon minced onion just a few minutes until golden; spoon over zucchini in casserole. 5 Using about 1/2 basket cherry tomatoes, cut tomatoes in half and arrange over mushrooms. (One large tomato, sliced, or well-drained canned tomatoes may be substituted.) 6 Season casserole with 1 clove garlic, minced, 1/2 teaspoon Italian seasoning herbs and salt and pepper to taste.

7 Cut about 3 ounces mozzarella cheese in strips and layer over tomatoes.

8 Sprinkle with 3 tablespoons bread crumbs, then 1 tablespoon Parmesan cheese and a dash of paprika.

9 Cover and bake in preheated 375°

name: MCP Pectin Instructions
transcript:
# $\mathcal{A}(C)$ 2 **PECTIN** – JAM & JELLY DIRECTIONS ## **TIPS FOR SUCCESS** Making homemade jams and jellies with MCP® Pectin is both funand easy. For best results, it is important to always follow these guidelines: - · Read all information first - · Follow recipe exactly. - . Do not reduce the amount of sugar called for in the recipe. The exact amounts of sugar, fruit, acid and pectin are necessary for a good set. - . Do not double recipes; mixture may not set. - . Use ripe fruit for best flavor and color. - . Crush, grind or finely chop all fruit thoroughly. - · Use proper size saucepot. - . Always add pectin before the sugar. - . A full rolling boil is a boil that does not stop when stirred. # **JAM AND JELLY MAKING AIDS** - . Decorative Contact Lobels (5 dozen) for \$1.75 and 1 UPC Symbol. - . Complete Juice Extracting Kit (includes jelly bog and filter paper) for \$5.50 and 3 UPC Symbols. - \* Replacement Jelly Bag for \$2.75 and 1 UPC Symbol. - . Replacement Filter Paper (100-2-pty sheets) for \$1.45 and 1 UPC. Symbol To order, send name and address with required number of MCP® Pectin UPC Symbols and check or money order to MCP® Premiums, P.O. Box 8274, Kankakee, IL 60902. # **NO-COOK FREEZER JAM DIRECTIONS** FRUIT NEEDED: Start with approximately 2 quarts berries or 3 pounds fruit at room temperature. . Store unopened packages of MCP® Pectin in a cool, dry place. ### **EQUIPMENT** Assemble the following pieces of equipment before starting to make jam or jelly: - For cooked jams and jellies: half pint (8 ounce) or pint (16 ounce) glass jelly jars - . For freezer jams and jellies: plastic containers (8 ounce) with tightfitting lids - Mixing spoon, measuring spoons - . Glass or plastic liquid measuring cup with pour spout for fruit pulp and other liquids - . Metal or plastic dry measuring cup with straight top edge for sugar - Potato masher or food grinder - . Bowls for preparing fruit and premeasuring sugar - 6- to 8-quart saucepot - . For jellies: MCP® Juice Extracting Kit or colander and cheesecloth # **MEASURE INGREDIENTS CAREFULLY** - . Use standard measuring cups and level measures for all ingredients, - . If a little short of juice for jellies, add up to 1/2 cup water. TO PREPARE CONTAINERS: Rinse clean plastic containers and lids with boiling water. #### **TO PREPARE FRUIT:** Berries and Grapes: Wash fruit. Stem and seed, if necessary. Grind or crush thoroughly until reduced to a pulp. Sieve 1/2 of the pulp to remove some seeds, if desired. Other Fruit: Wash. Peel figs, kiwis or peaches. Pit, slice and grind or finely chop. #### **TO PREPARE JAM:** - 1. MEASURE prepared fruit and lemon juice, if called for, into large bowl. Measure sugar into separate bowl. Set aside. Gradually stir 1 package MCP® Pectin into fruit; mix thoroughly. Set aside 30 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes to dissolve pectin thoroughly. - 2. POUR corn syrup into fruit mixture; mix well. This prevents sugar crystallization during freezer storage. - 3. STIR in sugar gradually. Continue stirring to dissolve completely. - 4. POUR into containers to within 1/2 inch of tops. Wipe off edges of containers; cover with lids. name: Nut Brittle Squares
transcript: NUT BRITTLE SQUARES Use any kind of nuts you choose for this crisp, crunchy candy. Butter the outside bottom of an 8"square pan and sprinkle evenly with 1. cup rather finely chopped Brazil nuts, filberts, California walnuts, pecans, peanuts or other nuts. Set pan nut-side up on a tray. Put 1 cup sugar in heavy skillet and heat, stirring until golden brown and syrupy. At once pour evenly over nuts. When slightly cooled, remove in one piece to a board and cut in 2" squares. Makes 16 squares, or 1/2 pound.

## **Chile and Cheese Tamales**

perromed this recipe from Raley's employee Ignacio Salcedo from our West Sacramento store. When look brings his tamples into the SE offices during the holidays, they're gone in a flash! that least 8 hours Cook: 1 hour Makes: 5 dozen

- nstant com masa flour

- **roasted eart into Street**

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

**1.** The day before making tamales, stir together masa, shortening, baking powder, salt and water in a large bowl until combined. (Add additional water as needed. It should be about the consistency of peanut butter.) Cover with a damp towel and refrigerate for at least 8 hours. 2. Remove masa from refrigerator and knead to soften. Spread about 1/3 cup masa on the upper half of each corn husk; top with equal amounts of cheese, poblano and a sprinkle of jalapeños. Fold in sides and bottom of husk; tie the folded end with small strips of corn husk to secure, if you like. (Tamales may be frozen at this point for up to 3 months.)

3. Place folded end down in a steamer basket and cook, covered, for 1 hour. Remove from heat and let stand for 10 minutes before serving.

name: Sunchokes Recipe
transcript:
## fresh

## **COOK NOW!** Sunchokes

Also called Jerusalem artichokes, seasonal sunchokes are actually tubers that resemble fresh ginger. Homely on the outside, sunchokes' creamy, potato-like flesh is nutty and slightly sweet and supplies ample folate, fiber, and vitamin C, plus 28 percent of your daily iron needs per 1-cup serving. Peeling is optional, but wash thoroughly before using.

Mash. Dice peeled sunchokes into 1-inch chunks; add to a large pot of boiling water. Reduce heat and cook until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain and transfer to a bowl; mash until smooth and stir in butter or coconut oil. Season to taste; garnish with minced, fresh chives.

Roast. Slice sunchokes lengthwise into 1/4-inch pieces; coat with olive oil and sprinkle with minced garlic, salt, pepper, and dried rosemary. Roast at 425 degrees until easily pierced with a knife, 15-20 minutes.

Raw. Using a mandolin slicer or a very sharp

- 3 tablespoons soy sauce
- 1/4 cup fine dry bread crumbs
- 1 green pepper, thinly sliced Hot cooked rice or chow mein noodles

Drain pineapple, reserving juice. Set aside pineapple. Add enough water to juice to make 11/3 cups liquid. In Mighty Pitcher combine liquid, brown sugar, cornstarch, vinegar and 1/3 cup soy sauce. Microwave at High for 71/2 to 11 minutes, or until mixture is thick and glossy, stirring twice with whisk. Set aside.

In medium mixing bowl, combine beef, pork, egg, 3 tablespoons soy sauce and bread crumbs. Mix well. Shape into 20 meatballs. Place meatballs and green peppers in 2-quart Oval Casserole in oven on Micro-Go-Round<sup>®</sup>. Microwave at High for 6 to 8 minutes, or until meat is no longer pink. Drain. Add pineapple chunks and sauce to meatballs. Microwave at High for 4 to 6 minutes, or until hot, stirring once. Serve over rice.

Remove eggs when they are still soft and moist. Let stand about 2 minutes. Eggs will firm up while standing. If desired, sprinkle with shredded cheese during standing time.

## Beef & Broccoli Stir-Fry

- 2 tablespoons cornstarch, divided
- 4 tablespoons Kikkoman Soy Sauce, divided
- I teaspoon sugar
- 2 teaspoons minced fresh ginger root

Cut beef across grain into thin slices. Combine 1 tablespoon each cornstarch and soy sauce with sugar, ginger and garlic; stir in beef. Let stand 15 minutes. Meanwhile, remove flowerets from broccoli; if large, cut in half lengthwise. Cut stalks crosswise into  $\frac{1}{6}$ -inch slices. Combine remaining cornstarch and soy sauce with 1 cup water; set aside. Heat 1 tablespoon oil in wok or large skillet over high heat. Add meat and stir-fry 1 minute; remove. Heat remaining oil in same wok Add broccoli, onion and carrot; stir-fry 4 minutes, or until vegetables are tender-crisp. Stir in meat and soy sauce mixture; bring to boil. name: Chicken Breasts Diane
transcript:
# SAMPLE Chicken Breasts Diane

Steak Diane is an ever-popular dish. Try this version with chicken breasts, slightly pounded for an interesting variation.

## Poultry at Its Best Card 47

### **TYPreparation time: 20 min.**

## For 4 servings you will need:

- 4 large boneless chicken breast halves or 8 small
- $\frac{1}{2}$  tsp. salt
- $\frac{1}{4}$  to  $\frac{1}{2}$  tsp. black pepper
- 2 Tbsp. olive or salad oil
- 2 Tbsp. butter or margarine
- 3 Tbsp. chopped fresh chives or green onions
- Juice of  $\frac{1}{2}$  lime or lemon 2 Tbsp. brandy or cognac, optional
- 3 Tbsp. chopped parsley
- 2 tsp. Dijon-style mustard
- $\frac{1}{4}$  cup chicken broth

### Tips:

You can pound chicken breasts flat and leave flattened between sheets of plastic wrap. Wrap them airtight in one package and freeze for later use.

## **Preparation:**

1 Place chicken breast halves between sheets of waxed paper or plastic wrap. Pound slightly with mallet. Sprinkle with salt and black pepper.

2 Heat 1 tablespoon each of oil and butter in large skillet. 8 Cook chicken over high heat for 4 minutes on each side. Do not cook longer or they will be over-

cooked and dry. Transfer to warm serving platter.

4 Add chives or green onion, lime juice and brandy, if used, pars ey and mustard to pan. Cook 15 seconds, whisking constantly. 5 Whisk in broth. Stir until sauce

is smooth. Whisk in remaining burner and oil.

**6** Pour sauce over chicken. Serve immediately.

27 708 12

name: Simple Syrup Recipe
transcript: **SIMPLE SYRUP** Combine 11/2 cups granulated sugar and 11/4 cups water in saucepan. Stirring occasionally, bring mixture to boil over medium-high heat. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes. Remove from heat; cool in pan. Refrigerate in glass jar up to 1 month. Makes about 2 cups. **BLACKBERRY LIQUEUR Gently** wash 3 cups fresh blackberries; dry on towels. Place blackberries in glass container with tightfitting lid. Wash, dry, and remove peel from 1 lemon, scraping any white pith from peel. Add lemon peel to blackberries. Using wooden spoon, gently mash blackberries and peel. Add one 750-milliliter bottle vodka; stir and seal jar. Place in cool, dry spot away from sunlight. Let sit 2 weeks, swirling occasionally. Add 1% cups Simple Syrup (see recipe above). Stir again; reseal. Let sit 2 more weeks. Strain liqueur through double layer of 100% cotton cheesecloth into pitcher. Strain again through

name: Greek Lemon Cake
transcript:
This feathery cake is lovely served with ice cream or fresh fruit marinated in a liqueur. 3 cups cake flour or 2-3/4 cups all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon baking soda 1/4 teaspoon salt 6 eggs, separated 2 cups sugar, divided 1 cup butter or margarine, softened 2 teaspoons grated lemon peel 2 tablespoons lemon juice 1 cup plain yogurt Stir together flour, soda and salt; set aside. In large bowl of mixer beat egg whites until soft peaks form. Gradually add 1/2 cup sugar, beating until stiff but glossy peaks form; set aside. Beat butter, remaining 1-1/2 cups sugar, egg yolks, lemon peel and juice until fluffy. Stir flour mixture alternately with yogurt into creamed butter mixture, then gently fold into egg-white mixture. Pour into greased 10-inch plain or fluted tube pan. Bake in preheated 350° oven 50 to 60 minutes or until pick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool in pan 10 minutes, then turn out on rack to finish cooling. Serves 12.

## **GREEK LEMON CAKE**

name: Kids' Chocolate Chip Oatmeal Cookies
transcript:
## Chocolate Chip Oatmeal Cookies

Here's a kid-pleasing recipe from the Better Homes and Gardens® New Junior Cook Book that cooks of all ages can enjoy.

1/2 cup margarine or butter (1 stick) 1egg 1 cup all-purpose flour

1/2 cup sugar 1/2 cup packed brown sugar 1 teaspoon vanilla

Remove the margarine or butter from the refrigerator at least 30 minutes before making the cookies. Turn oven to 375°. Put margarine in large bowl. Position electric mixer over bowl. Turn mixer to medium. Beat 30 seconds. Turn off mixer.

Crack the egg into the custard cup. Add the egg, flour, sugar, brown sugar, vanilla and baking soda to the margarine. Beat on medium speed about 2 minutes or till well mixed. As you mix, scrape sides of bowl with rubber scraper as needed. Turn off mixer. Use the wooden spoon to stir in oats and chocolate pieces.

Put enough dough on a small spoon so the dough is slightly humped. Use another spoon to push the dough from the spoon onto the cookie sheet. Repeat to fill cookie sheet. Leave about 2 inches between cookies.

Put the cookie sheet in the oven. Bake 8 to 10 minutes or till brown. While the cookies bake, drop more cookie dough onto the other cookie sheet. Use hot pads to remove the cookie sheet from the oven. Put the second cookie sheet into the oven. Use the pancake turner to lift the baked cookies onto the cooling rack. When the first cookie sheet is cool, drop more dough onto it. Repeat with remaining dough. Turn off the oven. Makes about 40 cookies.

name: Centsible Foods Recipe Collection
transcript:
# Centsible Foods—Fast and Frugal

**Counting pennies as** well as minutes? These quick dishes will please your pocketbook as well as your palate!

WHILE they may save time, storebought packaged entrees and carryout. restaurant meals aren't always moneysavers. So look here each issue for "centsible" express-eating alternatives that are as economical as they are appetizing. The payoff? Prompt meals and a plumper pocketbook.

## **PASTA SHELLS AND PEPPERS**

"Tomatoes and green peppers spooned over the top give this easy-to-prepare. macaroni and cheese fresh homemade taste," shares Sharon Ann Sluski from West Ossipee, New Hampshire, Our test kitchen figures her thrifty main dish costs just 94¢ per serving.

#### 1 cup cubed day-old bread Pinch onion sait

Pour the oil into an 8-in. square baking pan; add garlic. Bake at 325° until garlic is lightly browned, about 3-4 minutes. Add bread and onion salt; stir to coat. Bake 10-12 minutes longer or until the bread is lightly browned, stirring frequently. Store in an airtight container. Yield: 6 (2-tablespoon) servings.

- 1 package (1 pound) medium shell pasta
- 4 medium green peppers, cut into 1-inch chunks

  - 1 teaspoon salt

Cook pasta according to package directions. Meanwhile, in a skillet, saute peppers in butter for 2-3 minutes or until crisp-tender. Stir in tomatoes, sugar, salt and pepper; heat through. Drain pasta; stir in cheese until melted. Spoon into bowls; top with tomato mixture. Garnish with basil and/or oregano if desired. Yield: 6 servings.

#### **SALAD CROUTONS**

## **Focaccia Bread**

Serving suggestions: Great for breakfast, appetizers, sandwiches or with dinner.

## **Pizza Serving Ideas**

Garlic Chicken-spread focaccia with softened garlic cream cheese and top with diced chicken, havarti cheese and chopped green onions. Bake at 400 for 10-20 minutes.

Hawaiian Focaccia-top with thinly sliced ham, grated provolone cheese, chopped pineapple and slivered almonds. Bake at 400 for 10-20 minutes.

Mexican Focaccia-spread with refried beans, sprinkle with cheddar cheese, diced chicken or beef, olives and onions. Bake at 400 for 10-20 minutes. Cut into squares and serve topped with salsa and sour cream.

The B.L.T.-sprinkle focaccia with grated monterey jack cheese and cooked bacon (torn into pieces). Bake at 400 for 10-20 minutes then top with finely chopped lettuce and tomato.

Veggle Combo-spread with vegetable cream cheese. Sprinkie with chopped green onions, olives, tomatoes, bell pepper, marinated artichoke hearts and mushrooms. Bake at 400 for 10-20 minutes.

name: Oriental Soup Recipe
transcript:
You'll find other kitchen-tested recipes in the latest issue of **Better Homes and** Gardens® magazine.

**Nograph Mike Jensen** 

Our tasty Oriental soup makes the most of a calorie-cutting secret: reducing fat. It uses a homemade chicken stock that's been skimmed of fat, which contains 9 calories per gram. You save 100 calories for every tablespoon of the or oil you trim  $-$  and you still can enjoy full flavor. Try it today!

**Chicken Stock** In a Dutch oven place backs, necks, and wings from 2 chickens; 2 large stalks celery. cut up: 2 carrots, cut up; 1 large onion, cut up; 2 sprigs parsley; 1 bay leaf; 1/2 teaspoom dried thyme, crushed; 2 whole cloves; 1/2 teaspoon salt; and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Add 6 cups water. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Cover and simmer 11/4 hours. Remove chicken; strain stock by pouring through a colander or sieve lined with a double layer of cheesecloth. Discard solids. Clarify stock, if desired. If using stock hot, skim off fat. Or. chill for 6 to 8 hours and lift off fat. Makes 51/2 cups.

4 cups Chicken Stock

## **Oriental Soup**

16-ounce package frozen pea pods, thawed 2 cups diced fully cooked ham

1 cup sliced fresh mushrooms or one 4-ounce can sliced mushrooms, drained 1/4 cup sliced green onion 2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar

Prepare Chicken Stock (above). Bias-slice pea pods in half crosswise. Set aside. In a 3quart saucepan combine the Chicken Stock, ham, and mushrooms. Bring to beling. reduce heat. Cover; simmer 4 to 5 minutes.

Stir in pea pods and green onion. Cook 2 to 3 minutes more or till pea pods are crosstender. Stir in vinegar. Ladle into soup bowls. Serves 4.

dry with a towel. In a blender or food processor, combine basil leaves and 1 cup olive or vegetable oil (see notes). Whirl just until leaves are finely chopped (do not purée).

2. Pour mixture into a 1- to  $1^{1/2}$ -quart pan over medium heat. Stir occasionally until oil bubbles around pan sides and reaches 165° on a thermometer, 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from heat and let stand until cool, about 1 hour.

3. Line a fine wire strainer with two layers of cheesecloth and set over a small bowl. Pour oil mixture into strainer. After oil passes through, gently press basil to release remaining oil. Discard basil. Serve oil or cover airtight and store in the refrigerator up to 3 months. The olive oil may solidify slightly when chilled, but it will quickly liquefy when it comes back to room temperature. name: Suzette Crepes
transcript:
## CREPES SUZETTE (4 servings)

This famous flaming dessert is cradited in invantion to the Franco-American chef : Henri Charpentier.

While still quite young, Charpentier was working on a complicated crôpe sauce to present to his then patron Albert, Prince of Wales. The cordials in the sauce accidentally caught fire and the young chef, thinking both he and his sauce were ruined, acted quickly and plunged the crepes. into the boiling liquid, added

more liquers and let the sauce flame again. He presented his "invention". CREPES SUZETTE and Charpentier were both a brilliant success.

## CRÊPES **FOR BATTER**

Ingredients

- $\mathbf{3}$ eggs
- 2 tbls. all-purpose flour

Winda

- 1/2 pint fresh milk
- frew drops of Grand Marnier pinch of cinamon

3 tsp. of granulated sugar pinch of salt

Method :

Combine and stir until the ingredients are the consistency of thin cream.

Keep this batter anything from 3 hours until overnight covered and refrigerated. Cook in favourite crêpe pan, using favourite crêpe method. Or, if preferred, you can make same in a teflon frypan in which case we recommend adding to the batter one tsp. of golden brown fried butter.

Sauce:

(Note: Our chefs recommend using a silver plated frypan) Place into the frypan over a moderate heat following :

3-4 tbls. sugar peel of 1 orange peel of 1 lemon Cook until sugar melts and becomes brown (carmelizes) (DO NOT STIR while sugar is melting.) 1/2 tbls. butter ADD: juice of 2 oranges juice of 1 lemon Stir until well combined and heated through. Remove orange and lemon peels. Add crepes. Place unfolded crepe in pan, coat with sauce. Fold in half, then fold in half again. Repeat process with all remaining crepes. name: Corned Beef and Cabbage
transcript:
## **CORNED BEEF AND CABBAGE**

Wash well in cold water a 4-pound piece of corned beef. If desired, roll tightly and tie securely with heavy white string. Place

in a large kettle with tight-fitting cover. Add enough cold water to cover meat completely; bring slowly to boiling. Boil 5 minutes, removing scum as it comes to the surface. Reduce heat and simmer, covered, 3 to 4 hours, or until meat is tender, adding 1 medium-size cabbage, cut into sixths, about 20 minutes before end of cooking time. To serve, remove meat from stock and place on hot platter. Cut away strings, if you have rolled meat before cooking. Drain cabbage well and arrange around meat. Serve meat, sliced, with horseradish or mustard.

brown). Serve immediately with Creole Sauce (see below). A simple supper, but how tempting! You'll find fish or any food, for that matter, is extra delicious fried in Wesson Oil. Digestible, too! No wonder good cooks everywhere have been frying with famous Wesson Oil for years!

name: Pomegranate Jelly
transcript:
## Pomegranate Jelly

- 3 1/2 cups prepared pomegranate juice (about 8 to 10 fully ripe pomegranates)
  - 5 cups sugar
  - 1 package MCP PECTIN
  - 1/4 teaspoon margarine, butter or oil

Boil jars on rack in large pot filled with water 10 minutes. Place flat lids in saucepan with water. Bring to boil; remove from heat. Let stand in hot water until ready to fill. Drain well.

Submerge pomegranates in water and soak for 15 minutes. Break apart under water and separate seeds from membranes. Seeds will sink to the bottom while membranes, skin and rind will rise to the top. Skim the top and discard. Scoop up the seeds and place them in jelly cloth or bag. Squeeze out juice. Measure 3 1/2 cups into 6- or 8-quart saucepot.

Measure sugar and set aside. Mix fruit pectin into juice in saucepot. Place over high heat and stir until mixture comes to a full boil. Immediately add all sugar and stir. Bring to a full rolling boil. Add margarine and boil hard exactly 2 minutes, stirring constantly. Remove from heat and skim off foam with metal spoon. Ladle quickly into prepared jars, filling to within 1/8 inch of tops. Wipe jar rims and threads. Cover with two-piece lids. Screw bands tightly.\* Invert jars for 5 minutes, then turn upright. After 1 hour, check / seals.

\*Or follow water bath method recommended by USDA.

Makes 6 (1 cup) jars.

  - egg

Combine flour, baking soda, salt and cinnamon in small bowl. Beat butter, granulated sugar, brown sugar and peanut butter in large mixer bowl until creamy. Beat in egg and vanilla. Gradually beat in flour mixture. Stir in morsels and peanuts. Drop dough by rounded tablespoon onto ungreased baking sheets. Press down slightly to flatten into 2-inch circles.

When you plan to mail cookies, choose a recipe for firm cookies, avoiding soft, brittle or delicate varieties. Cookies tend to taste fresher longer when made with regular stick margarine instead of butter. After baking, cool completely, then wrap two cookies at a time, back to back, in

Dissolve yeast in warm water. Stir in sugar, salt, eggs, oil and 3 cups of the flour. Beat until smooth. Mix in enough remaining flour to make dough easy to handle.

Turn dough onto lightly floured board; knead until smooth and elastic, 8 to 10 minutes. Place in greased bowl; turn greased side up. (At this point, dough can be refrigerated 3 to 4 days.) Cover; let rise in warm place until double, about 1 hour. (Dough is ready if impression remains.) Punch down dough; divide in half. Roll each half into rectangle, 18x9 inches. Roll up, beginning at short side. With side of hand, press each end to seal. Fold ends under loaf. Place seam side down in greased loaf pan, 9x5x3 inches. Brush loaves with salad oil. Let rise until double, about 1 hour.

Heat oven to 375°. Place loaves on lower oven rack so that tops of pans are in center of oven. Pans should not touch each other or sides of oven. Bake 30 to 35 minutes or until deep golden brown and loaves sound hollow when tapped. Remove from pans. Brush loaves with butter; cool on wire rack. 2 loaves.

name: Egg Cooking Techniques
transcript:
If you can't even poach an egg, here are some basic egg-cooking techniques:

Hard-cooked eggs: Place eggs in a single layer in a saucepan. Add tap water to at least 1 inch above eggs. Cover. Quickly bring just to boiling. Turn off heat: remove pan from burner to prevent further boiling. Let eggs stand, covered, in the hot water, about 15 minutes for medium eggs, 18 minutes for large and 20 for extra-large. Immediately run cold water over the eggs or place them in ice water until completely cooled. To remove shell, crackle it by tapping it gently all over. Roll the egg between your hands to loosen the shell. Peel, starting at the large end. Hold the egg under running cold water or dip it in a bowl of water to help ease off the shell.

Soft-cooked eggs: Follow directions for hard-cooked eggs, but let eggs stand, covered, in hot water only about one to five minutes, depending on how done you prefer them. Place in egg cups, crack tops of shells and remove the tops to eat.

## COOKING EGGS 101

Poached eggs: In saucepan or deep skillet, bring 2 to 3 inches of water to boiling. Reduce heat to keep water gently simmering. Break cold eggs, one at a time, into custard cup or saucer. Hold dish close to water's surface; slip eggs into water. Cook until whites are completely set and yolks begin to thicken but are not hard, about three to five minutes. With slotted spoon, lift out eggs. Drain in spoon or on paper towels.

ramekin, shallow baking dish or 10-ounce custard cup. Spoon 1 tablespoon milk, half-and-half or light cream over eggs. Bake in preheated 325-degree oven until whites are completely set and yolks begin to thicken but are not

Baked (shirred) eggs: For one to two servings, break and slip two eggs into greased hard, about 12 to 18 minutes, depending on number of servings being baked.

Fried eggs: For one to two servings, in 7-to 8-inch omelet pan or skillet over medium-high heat, heat 1 teaspoon to 2 tablespoons butter or cooking oil (or use cooking spray) until just here enough to sizzle a drop of water. Break and sig-2 eggs into pan. Immediately reduce heat to low. Cook slowly until whites are completely set and yolks begin to thicken but are not hard. Cover tightly with a lid, spooning butter over easy to baste or turning eggs to cook both sides. For over easy or over hard, gently lift eggs with pancake turner and flip upside down into pan. Cook second side.

- 3 cups all-purpose flour
- 1 teaspoon baking soda
- 1 teaspoon salt
- 2 cups sugar
- 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- 3 large eggs, beaten lightly
- 3/4 cup vegetable oil

**110 Family Circle** 

- 1 cup chopped pecans
- 2 large ripe bananas, mashed
- 1 can (8 ounces) crushed pineapple, undrained
- 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract Frosting:

1. Cake: Heat oven to 350°. Butter and flour two 9-inch cake pans. 2. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, salt, sugar and cinnamon. Add the eggs and oil. Stir until dry ingredients are just moistened. Stir in the pecans, bananas, pineapple and vanilla. Evenly divide batter between the prepared pans.

3. Bake at 350° for 28 minutes or until toothpick inserted into center of cake comes out clean. Cool on wire rack for 15 minutes. Turn out and cool completely. 4. Frosting: In a large bowl, beat the cream cheese and butter until creamy. Gradually sift in the confectioners' sugar. Beat in vanilla.

5. Place one cake layer on serving plate. Spread about 1 cup frosting over top. Place second layer on top. Frost top and sides of cake. Refrigerate for at least 1 hour before serving.

1. Preheat oven to 350°F.

2. Combine honey and Lea & Perrins Worcestershire Sauce in a bowl. Brush ribs on both sides with the mixture. Place ribs in a shallow baking pan. Bake for 30 minutes basting twice with sauce.

name: Apricot Liqueur Recipe
transcript: 108 MARINATED APRICOTS **AND LIQUEUR** Two gifts in one: liqueur for drinking, apricots for dessert 8 ounces dried apricots (1-1/3 cups packed) 8 ounces white rock candy 1-1/2 cups vodka (least-expensive kind) Layer apricots and candy in wide-mouth 1-quart glass bottle or glass jar. Pour on vodka. Cover airtight (if cork top is used, first wrap cork in plastic wrap or foil). Let stand at room temperature 2 to 3 weeks or until candy is dissolved, stirring twice. Makes about 1-3/4 cups liqueur, about 2 cups apricots. To serve, drain liqueur into decanter; serve after dinner. Apricots are good with walnuts in the shell or over ice cream. Will keep indefinitely.
